Graphical abstract The polynary-atom catalysts (PACs) enhance catalytic performance via intermetallic synergy. This review explores the sources of catalyst activity and mechanisms for performance improvement in relation to PACs. Throughout versatile metal compositions and unique structural characteristics, polynary metal atom catalysts (PACs) readily harness synergistic intermetallic effects, significantly boosting the catalytic performances. These catalysts are featured by favorable catalytic activity, stability and selectivity, offering avenues to tackle challenges in energy conversion, environmental protection and chemical synthesis. Nevertheless, an in-depth understanding and comprehensive summary of the structure-performance relationship for the emerging PACs remains elusive. This review embarks from the classification of PACs, delving further into the origins of catalytic activity and mechanisms underpinning performance enhancement. At the beginning, it outlines the fundamental concepts, preparation methods and accurate recognition of PACs. Subsequently, it centers on discussing the origins of activity, strategies for performance optimization, mechanisms of action, and application scenarios across diverse catalytic reactions. Moreover, the unexplored issues and future perspectives of PACs are proposed at the end, stating their pivotal roles in advancing green chemistry and the sustainable energy realm. This review overall aims to provide valuable insight and guidance for the preparation and application of PACs. Keywords Polynary-atom catalyst Controllable synthesis Versatile interaction Influencing mechanism 1 Introduction The transformation and storage of sustainable energy are paramount in the global energy transition at present. Amid the relentless rise in the demand for clean energy sources, the pursuit of highly efficacious catalysts has become an indispensable strategy to fulfill their potential goals [1–3]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have readily garnered considerable attention because of outstanding performances in broad spectra of catalytic reactions, where the unique electronic/geometric features distinguish them from typical congeners in a nanoparticle or nanocluster form [4–7]. Nevertheless, the capability of SACs pertaining to concurrently catalyzing multi-intermediate reactions is constrained by the absence of cooperative catalysis from proximate centers [8]. Furthermore, the reactant adsorption and product desorption in certain pathways necessitate the collaborative action of adjacent metal moieties. These aspects accordingly retard the usage of SACs in pivotal chemical processes [9]. As compared to SACs, polynary-atom catalysts (PACs) might deliver superior catalytic performances owing to their sufficient active sites, unique electronic architectures and synergistic atom geometries (Fig. 1 ) [10–12]. To date, such an enhancement has been exquisitely demonstrated by integrating bimetallic configurations [13]. For instance, Hai et al. reported a class of geminal-atom catalysts affording single-atom pairs in specific coordination and spatial proximity [9]. As for Cu geminal sites with high metal density, the adaptable coordination of Cu enables a cooperative bridge-coupling route through dynamic CuCu bonding for diverse CX (X = C, N, O, S) cross-couplings with a low activation barrier. Consequently, the rational design of PACs holds promise not only for achieving specific activity, pronounced selectivity and convenient recyclability in energy-related fields, but also for offering tantalizing possibilities to address environmental issues [14]. Unfortunately, review articles involving systematic discussion and outlook of emerging PACs in this realm are relatively lacking. A timely insight into the applicable customization, tailorable fabrication and deployable application of PACs is imperative [15]. In this review, drawing upon both theoretical and empirical evidences, we summarize recent advances in the target design, controlled preparation and performance demonstration of PACs (Fig. 2 ). At the first stage, we comprehensively outline the types of PACs, followed by detailing the strategies for their synthesis and identification. This deals with the meticulous manipulation of the species, quantity, spatial arrangement, and coordination environment of metal atoms within the catalyst matrix. We then delve into the active origins of PACs, encompassing discussions with respect to intermetallic electron transfer, synergistic effect modulation, and interfacial interaction, which collectively shape the catalytic prowess of the material. In turn, we provide mechanistic elucidation of intricate structure–activity relationship in PACs toward governing intermediate formation and transformation as well as kinetic features of the catalytic reactions. This provides theoretical support for the enhancement of activity in CO2 reduction (CO2RR), Oxygen reduction (ORR), Hydrogen evolution (HER), Oxygen evolution (OER), Nitrogen reduction reactions (NRR), and other catalytic conversion reactions by PACs (Fig. 3 ). Ultimately, we conclude by proposing the challenges and prospects associated with the rational design and practical employment of PACs, aiming to foster future research and innovation endeavors in this promising field. 2 Category of PACs To break the linear scaling relationship and harvest impressive catalytic performance, various PACs have been developed, which have showcased potential usages in the catalytic reactions in the energy- and environment-related realms. In general, the design of PACs relies heavily upon the synergistic functions among poly-metal centers [16–18]. Nonetheless, different types of PACs with unique electronic/geometric structures would possibly tailor the catalytic reactions in distinct manners [19]. Admittedly, rational classification of PACs with the aid of clear atomic-scale identification is meaningful to understanding catalysis pathways and pinpointing optimal candidates. With the consideration of the state-of-the-art PACs, five major types of PACs could be categorized (Fig. 4 ), encompassing coplanar adjacent (I), coplanar bridged (II), coplanar discrete (III), coplanar hybrid (I + II, I + III), and nonplanar (IV). 3 Controllable synthesis of PACs 3.1 Coplanar adjacent PACs (Type I) Coplanar adjacent type is normally featured by the coordination structure of M1–M2 (and/or –M3, etc.), which comprises the identical or distinct metal centers connected by metal–metal bonding as the coplanar dimer, trimer, or low-nuclearity clusters. Such PACs have recently received ever-increasing attention because of the benefiting synergy from bonded metal active sites [20,21]. Moreover, strong bonding through orbital coupling has been considered a useful tool to enhance interactions between metal centers [22]. There exist two typical sub-groups, including homonuclear and heteronuclear forms. 3.1.1 Bonded homonuclear types PACs with homonuclear metal atoms, serving as an extension of SACs, are expected to further increase the atom loading and augment the active centers. Outstanding catalytic performances could be gained by the synergistic effect from the bonded identical nuclei. Despite these merits, their controllable preparation has still remained challenging, with several synthetic tactics devised in this realm. Precursor selection. Pre-selected precursors possess homogeneous and stabilized metal species, which could be crucial in the precise synthesis of quantitative polymetallic centers. To explore atom-by-atom relations between structure and function in low-nuclearity PACs, metal species with different nuclearity were accommodated onto carbon nitride (CN) [23]. The available [PdCl(C3H5)]2 and [Pd(OAc)2]3 were exploited to fabricate PACs affording Pd dimers (Pd2/ECN) and trimers (Pd3/ECN). The high metal dispersion as dimers and trimers could be identified by aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-STEM) observation. Similarly, typical organometallic complexes such as Fe2(CO)9, Fe3(CO)12 and Ru3(CO)12 could be stabilized by metal–organic framework (ZIF-8), which are prone to directly form accurate homonuclear metal sites upon heat treatment [24–28]. Leng et al. reported a series of monodispersed poly-metal sites (Fe, Cu, Ir) by an interfacial cladding auxiliary strategy to suppress atomic thermal migration [29]. As illustrated in Fig. 5 a, metal dimer molecules are immobilized on the surface of ZIF-8 by the polydopamine coating, which not only prevents undesired metal aggregation under heat treatment but also achieves well-defined N-coordinated homonuclear poly-metal atoms. According to intensity profiles extracted from AC-STEM images, the distance of adjacent Fe, Cu and Ir atoms lay in ∼2.2, 2.3 and 2.6 Å, respectively. The Fourier transform extended X-ray absorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) spectra displayed two peaks at 1.4–1.5 Å and 2.2–2.4 Å that could be ascribed to metal–N and metal–metal bonds, in agreement with the distance statistics. The fitting results at the R-space further revealed the M2N6 configuration with obvious metal bonding. Despite the potential for precise synthesis using ready-made precursors, tedious fabrication procedures and high-cost aspects might preclude scalable synthesis. To this end, Li et al. devised Pd2 DAC via anion replacement deposition–precipitation method. The binuclear Pd(II) complex as the precursor, specially prepared in advance, was deposited on the surface of acetylene black owing to the substitution of NO3 − by KPF6 to attain atomically dispersed Pd dual atom pairs [30]. Such a simple preparation procedure guarantees mass production under mild conditions. Ligand customization. Under proper environments, the customized organic ligand could effectively capture and stabilize the paired metal atoms, thereby preventing the metal atoms from agglomeration during post-treatment. This would enable the expected homonuclear PACs. Liang et al. successfully synthesized a Ni2 DAC with high reproducibility [31]. Concretely, two organic ligands, H2qpyrc and H2qpyzc, were pre-designed for forming Ni SAC and Ni2 DAC via respectively employing 1H pyrazole-2-carboxylic acid and 1H pyrazole-3-carboxylic acid complex, which could be distinguished by 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) analysis. As compared with H2qpyrc, H2qpyzc possesses the ability to establish dual Ni sites on carbon nanotubes (CNTs) upon heat treatment because of an additional N structure (Fig. 5b). Remarkably, 90.1% of Ni diatomic pairs were statistically counted based on AC-STEM characterization, suggesting the precise synthesis of DACs. Wavelet transformed k 2-weighted EXAFS analysis was carried out to clarify the coordination structures for the Ni species. Apparently, the presence of NiN and NiNi coordination signals imply the Ni2 N6 configuration (Fig. 5c). Moreover, a supramolecule pyrolysis method, originating from the coordination of inserted Co salts with melamine and cyanuric acid frameworks was reported [32]. With the increase of Co atomic content and weight ratio, two cobalt moieties could be simultaneously combined within the precursors, therefore transforming into the Co-DACs. The simulated scanning tunneling microscope (STM) image in Fig. 5d clearly illustrates that two Co atoms are incorporated. Fourier transformed radial distribution functions of k 3-weighted EXAFS oscillations of the Co K-edge reveal that CoDAC harvests CoN and CoCo coordination in contrast to the merely CoN structure of Co-SAC (Fig. 5e). Similarly, Li et al. employed pyrolysis of supramolecular precursors to prepare homo-diatomic Fe sites [33]. Metal-organic layers (MOLs), a class of 2D crystalline layered materials derived by solvothermal methods, have been extensively employed in catalysis fields owing to well-defined structures and exposed catalytic moieties [34]. Recently, Liao et al. prepared a single-layer MOL (Cuobpy-SL) with confined dual-copper sites by adopting a facile one-pot solvothermal route [35]. Benefiting from the space-confined effect of DACs, thus-acquired Cuobpy-SL harvests an impressive catalytic performance in contrast to the single-copper sites and completely exposed dual-copper sites (Fig. 5f). Substrate design. Poly-metal atoms would show uniform dispersion and ideal coordination microenvironment over designed substrates with the increase of metal loading. Ma and colleagues utilized a hybrid nanodiamond-graphene (ND@G) support to construct a Pd3/ND@G catalyst by a deposition–precipitation strategy by augmenting the Pd loading [36]. In turn, Pd3 clusters enabled the direct dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene at a low temperature. Recently, ZIF-8 and ferrierite zeolite were used as the prevailing substrate to anchor metal species via in-situ ionic exchange or wetness impregnation [37–39]. By adding metal salts, homonuclear metallic sites were prone to form upon carbonization. Apart from carbon-based support, ultrathin Rh nanosheets (Rh NSs) were designed to precisely control the Pt atomic dispersion [40]. By virtue of the amorphous-to-crystalline transition, dual-Pt and multi-Pt atomic materials are controllably embedded by simply adjusting the feeding dosages of Pt precursors, respectively (Fig. 5g). The obvious bright spots and corresponding intensity of PtPt pair are observed from Pt2-Rh NSs. Such a unique pairwise Pt2-on-Rh coordination architecture further enabled high-efficiency and anti-CO alkaline hydrogen oxidation. 3.1.2 Bonded heteronuclear types In comparison with the structurally symmetric homonuclear PACs, heteronuclear PACs synergize the features of different metals, which would cause asymmetric spatial environments and electronic states to catalyze complex reactions. Nevertheless, it is still challenging to accurately build heteronuclear sites with desirable atom numbers. Precursor design. The dual solvent method combined with a host–guest strategy or mature technique such as atomic layer deposition (ALD) has been regarded as an effective means to construct heteronuclear metal bonding moieties. Typically, a type of Zn/Co-MOF was employed as a confined space incorporating Co2+ as the host [41–44]. To mitigate the adsorption resistance in cavities, aqueous Fe3+ solution as the guest was dosed into Zn/Co-MOF dispersed hydrophobic hexane solvent to combine with Co via immiscible solvent effect. Such a fully immobilized Fe/Co Zn-MOF was prone to form N-coordinated FeCo sites during pyrolysis and reduction. The presence of FeCo bond in (Fe, Co)/N-C can be witnessed by 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy (Fig. 5h). In a similar way, diverse PACs with heteronuclear FeNi or FeCo moieties were prepared for catalyzing complex reactions [45–48]. As for the ALD route, Sun et al. employed Pt and Ru gas-phase precursors in a sequential manner to build PtRu bonding dimers affording high activity and excellent stability (Fig. 5i) [44]. Such a synthetic strategy would pave the way toward a precise synthesis of other poly-metal dimers, trimmers and even tetramers [49]. Recently, Yang et al. presented a gas phase diffusion method for preparing a series of X/Fe-N-C (X = Pd, Ir or Pt) diatomic catalysts via processing X@ZIF-8 via ferrocene vapor [50]. The 3D intensity of a Pd/Fe dual atom pair and the electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) further indicate the co-existence of Pd and Fe elements in the poly-metal catalysts (Fig. 5j, k). More encouragingly, based on a metal single atom (M1) planted on polymeric carbon nitride (PCN), Lu et al. successfully introduced the secondary metal atom (M2) attached to M1 by the negative charge accumulation upon photo-excitation. Such a ‘navigation and positioning’ strategy is anticipated for precise and scalable synthesis of heteronuclear PAC series [51]. Ligand customization. Although MOFs and their derived NC, especially ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 based, have been widely used to coordinate polymetallic atoms, it remains difficult to merely rely upon themselves as the desirable bonding targets. The additional strong ligand with suitable selection could expectedly inhibit metal aggregation to a certain extent and achieve target-bonded heteronuclear PACs. Intriguingly, MOF or SiO2 modified by polydopamine (PDA) coating were found effective to form bonded poly-metal centers [52–55]. Typically, stemming from formamide condensation and carbonization, Sun et al. achieved the universal preparation of polymetallic (ZnFe, ZnCo, ZnFeCo) bonded catalysts on various supports [56]. Similarly, atomically dispersed FeCo carbon nanofiber, N/O dual coordinated NiZn and FeCo-N-C were reported through combining the electrospun polymer polyacrylonitrile (PAN) (Fig. 5l) [57–59]. Chitosan functioning as N and C sources can also coordinate with the mixed metal salts via the competitive complexation of NH2 and OH groups. As such, atomically dispersed ZnCo, NiZn and FeCo heteronuclear sites were realized by pyrolysis [45,60,61]. In addition, NC derived from hydroxylamine hydrochloride and glucose was employed to successfully disperse a series of FeZn, RuNi and CuSn dimers [62–64]. Substrate design. Like the fabrication of homonuclear PACs, a proper preselected substrate would possibly guide the direct formation of heteronuclear PACs. Recently, Zhang et al. utilized nitric acid and urea to treat holey N-doped graphene oxide (GO), which was then used to capture Fe/Cu metal salts. After hydrothermal treatment and annealing steps, Fe–Cu dimers were precisely formed, with mass loadings of 3.3 wt% for Fe and 2.8 wt% for Cu [65]. Thus “Y type” structure of N2Fe-CuN2 was figured out by fitting and modeling of FT-EXAFS data (Fig. 5m), which presents low energy consumption and high activity for reducing nitrate to ammonia. Typically, to preclude uneven sites in pyrolysis or ALD processes, a method was devised by using Fe-N4 decorated nanodiamond surface to anchor Pt single atoms via moderate thermal reduction, thereby attaining N3Fe-PtN3 architecture [66]. Recently, a series of Pt and Mo combinational species ranging from single atoms to nanoclusters was designed through nitrogen defect regulation and sequential metal deposition on NC support (Fig. 5n) [67]. TiO2 with abundant Ti-deficiencies and O-vacancies (OV) also showed the potential to stabilize adjacent RuIn couple sites [68]. Similarly, combining the synergistic effect with OV centers, PdCuTiO2 PACs improved CO2 chemisorption and CN coupling in contrast with Pd/CuTiO2 [69]. Collectively, we have summarized the controllable preparation routes and precise characterization means for the state-of-the-art coplanar adjacent PACs. Based on the metal bonding effect, many studies have successfully constructed and demonstrated the distinctive interaction of charge transfer and redistribution between neighboring poly-metal centers. Despite these advancements, daunting challenges remain in the development of high-purity, high-density and high-activity PACs, as well as in the refinement of identification technologies that are not only more accurate but also user-friendly and capable of quantitative assessments. 3.2 Coplanar bridged PACs (Type II) Coplanar bridged PACs harvest a metal connection pattern as M1 XM2 (or XM3, etc.; X: N, O, S, etc.). Among them, heteroatoms can effectively connect polymetallic centers by bridging one or more atoms at the first and/or second coordination sphere to form PACs with different coordination environments. The resultant non-direct bonding interaction and distance effect between nonmetal bridging metal atoms might be the key to breaking the catalytic bottleneck. In this sense, heteroatoms bridged PACs have been in target designed for heterogeneous catalysis. 3.2.1 Single heteroatom bridged through first shell Each type of bridging, featured by its unique intrinsic properties, exerts distinct coordinative effects on metal centers. The N atom bridge as a prevalent form has been widely probed. To rationally modulate the electronic structure of PACs, Zhong and co-workers designed single N bridged Ni2 sites (Ni2-N3C4) by pyrolysis of nickel precursor integrated with dicyandiamide and carbon black at 900 °C [70]. The measured distance between metal atoms was approximately 3.1 Å, falling within the range of 2.5–3.5 Å, which might represent one of the key characteristics of single heteroatom bridged PACs. Recently, Li et al. reported an N-bridged Co and Ni polyatomic catalyst (Co-N-Ni) by simple polymerization-pyrolysis of melamine, L-aspartic acid and metal salts [71]. The proximity distance between the Co and Ni was quantified and determined to be 3.59 ± 0.56 Å, setting the stage for spatial and electronic interactions. The detailed structure of Co-N-Ni was further demonstrated by EXAFS characterization and the fitting, which was determined as the Co-N4 and Ni-N4 sharing an N site in the first shell (Fig. 6 a, b). In another attempt, the d-block Cu metal was introduced to underpin the catalytic activity of the p-block In atom by carbonization of urea mixed CuCl2 with MIL-68(In). The resulting structure was also identified as a Cu-In PAC featuring N atoms as bridging ligands [72]. Equally important, the O atom with high electron negativity is recognized as outstanding charge regulator. For instance, Xie et al. developed the catalyst with two Cu atoms bridged by an O atom active site by assembling and heating CuCl2 with 2,2,-bipyridine (C10H8N2) and oxalic acid on g-C3N4 (Fig. 6c) [73]. Estimated by EXAFS and STEM results, ∼70% of Cu atoms are in CuOCu, suggestive of the effective preparation for target configuration. Such a O-bridged geometric structure with average distance of 2.8 ± 0.2 Å and CuOCu angle of 99.6° would potentially create unique synergetic effect. Similarly, the O-bridged Fe and W atoms are embedded in CN vacancies to synthesize Fe-W-CN by pre-fixing and pyrolysis process [74]. Intriguingly, the introduction of WO sites promote to stabilize the Fe single atoms and prevent the form of metal oxides. In virtue of the surface reactions of ALD, the dense atomic Cu grippers (8.1 wt%) on g-C3N4 enable great structural flexibility of highly loaded atomic Ni (3.1 wt%), which could lead to the O bridged Ni1Cu2 triangular trimers or linear trimers (Fig. 6d) [75]. Not limited to the statistical analysis of specific structure by HAADF-STEM images, advanced characterization such as Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) and Temperature-Programmed Desorption (TPD) further illustrate more than 70% of the main active sites as linear trimers (Fig. 6e). According to intensity profiles and EELS analysis of poly-atom sites, the linear CuNiCu structure with two unequal atomic distances of 2.61 ± 0.14 and 3.04 ± 0.13 Å on average are furnished (Fig. 6f). Apart from carbon-based materials, some vacancy-enriched transition metal oxides such as TiO2 and CeO2 are put forward to anchor metal atoms with O-coordinated, which directly form the neighboring M1 OM2 structure by multi-step heating and other methods [76,77]. In addition, the introduced P from PH3 can coordinate with Fe and Co on CN substrate to change the N coordination environment and enhance interactions of polymetallic atoms via the bridging effect [78]. Recently, Ding et al. constructed Pd and Ru diatomic sites supported on vinyl-functionalized porous ionic polymers through wetness impregnation to improve the poor stability of heterogeneous PACs [79]. The stronger charge interaction between in-situ generated anionic (Pd-I-Ru)− sites and cationic support showed unprecedented activity and relative long stability. 3.2.2 Multi heteroatoms bridged through first shell To build a more stable configuration, atomically dispersed PACs are prone to connect by multi-heteroatoms bridged in the first coordination shell according to thermodynamics and DFT calculation [80]. How to effectively construct the first shell bridging structure with different heteroatoms is equally important. The metal–2X–metal active sites can be directly developed by pyrolysis using the prefabricated poly-nuclear precursor (such as MOFs). For instance, for the preparation of structurally uniform Ni2NNi sites, MOF-derived NC and Ni2(dppm)2Cl3 precursor are pyrolyzed [81]. The N-bridged Ni2-N6 structure shows an approximate distance of 2.6 Å, which is in accord with the geometry characteristic of two heteroatomic bridge catalysts. Owing to the absence of metal bonding, XAS results only indicate the M-N signal. Encouragingly, a general synthetic strategy for constructing PACs with O-bridged homo- and hetero-polymetallic centers by dinuclear macrocyclic precursor-mediated was put forward [82]. In detail, the prefabricated poly-metal complex with a unique planar structure of (M1M2N4O2) can be used to build various PACs by tuning metal centers and targeting for precise M1 2OM2 sites after ZIF-8 encapsulation and pyrolysis (Fig. 6g). As for the detection of active sites, taking FeCu-DAC as an example, conventional characterization of EELS and XAS are employed for the identification of Fe2OCu pairs. To further provide unambiguous evidence, TOF-SIMS is carried out to compare FeCu-DAC with Fe/Cu-SAC (Fig. 6h), which demonstrates such a successful controllable preparation process. The additional appropriate ligand source or some auxiliary strategies would be instrumental in constructing the desired configuration. Among these, by in-situ electrochemical conversion of metal ions, a series of double-O bridge PACs were prepared based on the structure of Fe, Co and Ni embedded in NC [83]. Moreover, based on ZIF-8, many attempts have been made to bridge the polynary metal centers. Typically, Li et al. attempted to prepare ultra-thin 2D Fe2NMn site catalysts through a molten salt-assisted pyrolysis strategy [84]. Thus adjacent structure of N-bridged FeN4 and MnN4 shows excellent bifunctional ORR and OER performance. Subsequently, Fe2NCo structures prepared by a similar method are conducted for favorable bidirectional and selective conversion of polysulfide [85]. Combined with chemical vapor deposition (CVD), through electrospinning and subsequent pyrolysis, individual Cu atoms are anchored to interconnected porous carbon fibers (Fe x /CuN@CF) to form a Cu2NFe2NFe configuration [86]. Similarly, N-bridged triangular FeCoZn PACs are built by Li et al., which possess special synergistic interaction [87,88]. Not limited to d-d electronic interaction, Du and co-workers constructed the PACs which have a p (In)-d (Co) orbital hybrid structure through a facile pyrolysis of ZIF-8 precursor. Afterward, the uniform dual atom pairs are distinctly detected with an approximate distance of 2.72 Å and qualitatively identified different atomic intensities as hetero- Co2NIn sites by Z-contrast analysis (Fig. 6i). In particular, mixed heteroatoms bridged PACs would induce striking interaction effect. Based on Lewis's Hard-Soft-Acid-Base theory, the Fe3+-thioacetamide coordination compounds integrate with ZIF-8, utilizing sulfur and ammonium groups to form a dual-bridged connection between Fe and Zn atoms, specifically through S and N bonding [89]. Such a bi-functional ligand-assisted synthesis strategy predictively controls the distance of Fe and Zn atomic pairs as about 3.0 Å, which is crucial for ORR performance. Encouragingly, a universal and scalable atomization and thermal migrating strategy, which involves introducing melamine into Co-hollow polymer spheres and modulating the pyrolysis time, is rationally designed for 22 distinct PACs. This strategy provides the formation mechanism and guidance for N/O bridged poly-metal atom sites [90]. Recently, an additional O bridge auxiliary dual N-bridged connected configuration was put forward [91]. The unique structure, derived from the high-temperature reduction of polymetallic materials with ligands containing N and O, can be recognized by combining EELS and XAS [92,93]. 3.2.3 Multi heteroatoms bridged through first and second shell Certainly, a special class of PACs, featuring multi-N-bridged active sites in the form of Co2N2NPt, is designed by embedding Pt stripped from a glassy carbon electrode during electrochemical activation into defects within Co-NC derived from Co-MOF (Fig. 6j) [94]. Benefiting from fast Fourier transformation (FFT) and inverse FFT, the local coordination environment of bridging metal atoms can be distinctly identified (Fig. 6k). Based on ZIF-8, there have been many attempts. In order to enable the targeted preparation connected Fe-N4 and Co-N4 moieties, Bu et al. reported the “pre-constrained metal twins” strategy by pre-anchoring Fe and Co into binuclear phthalocyanine (PC) [95]. Thus-acquired FeCoPC rings with specific atomic distance are uniformly implanted in ZIF-8 as pyrolysis precursors for controllable preparation of desired poly-metal-center units (Fig. 6l). Also, a molten salt medium-induced infiltration deposition strategy was put forward to build neighboring Cu2N2NCo sites during pyrolysis [96]. The similar N8V4 vacancies structure has also been systematically studied and prepared, based on ZIF-8 derived NC, to anchor Co/Ni or Ni/Fe for a particular synergistic effect that enhances certain properties [97,98]. Recently, Zhang and co-workers achieved regulation of the distribution of Fe-N4 by changing Fe(Phen)3 complex loading on the MgO template [99]. Compared with the Fe2NFe distance of 2.6 Å, the 2Fe-N4 structure with a distance of 4.1 Å shows similar results to those of previous research, which suggests the practicability of this strategy. (Fig. 6m). Encouragingly, through profile coating of various bimetal Prussian blue analogues on the surface of supramolecular aggregates and the subsequent thermal treatment, a universal poly-atom design strategy is introduced for controllable preparation of multi-N bridged PACs [100]. In this section, we divide the coplanar bridged PACs into three categories in light of the number and coordination sphere of heteroatomic bridges. Meanwhile, the synthesis and identification techniques of various specific structures are roughly sketched out. The bridged PACs with a steerable coordinated environment and flexible atomic distance are endowed with the more adaptable poly-site adsorption and catalysis for the reaction intermediate. Hence, a more precise preparation strategy and more credible characterization means are anticipated for further attempts and exploration. 3.3 Coplanar discrete PACs (Type III) Coplanar discrete PACs are mononuclear metal single atoms dispersed on the substrate without rigorous spacing but outside the third shell among metal centers (usually with a distance >5 Å), and the configuration can be abbreviated as M1 + M2 (or +M3, etc.). For most PACs, metal loading is limited and usually maintained at low levels to prevent undesirable metal aggregations, which directly impact the overall catalytic performance. Notably, this type of poly-metal site is not directly connected and is composed of discrete metal centers coordinated by the surrounding chelating atoms, which is conducive to high metal loading on various dimensional supports. 3.3.1 1D supports Among various nanoscale materials, 1D nanomaterials such as nanotubes, nanofiber and nanorods with uniform structure, orientated electronic and ionic transport, and strong tolerance to stress change, are regarded as the promising supports to design versatile PACs [101]. Among them, carbon atoms in nanotubes can form a conjugated π network structure through sp2 hybridization, which is instrumental in electron transfer [102]. However, it is not easy to overcome the surface tension to promote metal sources' impregnation, and may produce unwanted impurities during the pyrolysis or arc evaporation process. For instance, a type of carbon nitride nanotube (CNNT) encapsulating FePC and CuPC is treated by a supercritical reaction at high pressure (50 bar) and zero-surface tension, resulting in ∼7.1 wt% loading of discrete Fe-N4 and Cu-N4 metal sites [103]. Typically, combined with coaxial electrospinning and carbonization processes, Fu et al. designed FePC and CuPc derived Fe and Cu single atoms embedded core–shell fibers (Fig. 7 a) [104]. Therein, the hollow carbon nanofiber architecture can effectively regulate the distribution of Fe and Cu cites with an interatomic distance of about 5 Å. Notably, the FT EXAFS results demonstrate that the FeN bonds occur expand and contract after successively introducing Cu SAs and magnetic field, indicative of successful design PACs on 1D supports. In addition, by virtue of fused-ring aromatic backbones and well-defined molecular structures, metal phthalocyanine molecules can integrate with CNT sidewalls via supramolecular π-π interaction and transform into M-N sites. Thereby, a two-step specific adsorption strategy (pyrolysis-free) was employed to construct PAC featuring FeCo molecular heterostructures (FeCo-MHs) formed by CoPc overlapping on FePC (Fig. 7b) [105]. Remarkably, in order to discriminate the poly-atom sites, in situ rotation (by 8°) in AC HAADF-STEM measurements and EELS are further conducted, which offers a new characterization protocol for the accurate identification of PACs. Besides, studies have been conducted on the initiation of aniline polymerization and pyrolysis using Co-doped MnO2 nanorods, leading to the development of high-activity poly-site Mn/Co-NC [106]. Despite all this, discrete poly-atom sites supported on 1D materials are still not common due to the lack of anchoring sites leading to the easy formation of nanoparticles and clusters. 3.3.2 2D supports Benefitting from the large surface area with abundant defects (vacancy and coordination atoms) and excellent flexibility, 2D materials are expected to validly anchor more polymetallic active sites. In this regard, 2D carbon nitride featuring isolated nitrogen groups can stabilize polynary metal species via delocalized π-bonding. Recently, Lu and co-workers reported on heterogeneous geminal Cu catalysts derived from polymeric carbon nitride, by exploiting the abundant and periodic presence of NH functional groups as Cu atomic replacement and coordination sites (Fig. 7c). These sites can be detected through the intensity of vibration bands related to the NH group (Fig. 7d) [9]. The HAADF-STEM imaging reveals that thus-acquired PAC (Cug/PCN) possesses a high concentration of metal atoms (18.3 wt% Cu), which tend to form regularly spaced pairs (termed as bistate Cu), with an average Cu-Cu distance of approximately 0.4 nm (Fig. 7e). Furthermore, the FT EXAFS spectrum exhibits a dominant feature centered at 1.5 Å, corresponding to the first shell CuN bond, and a weaker peak at 2.2 Å, representing the second shell CuC spacing (Fig. 7f). This suggests the presence of a discrete but cooperative pair single-atom structure. Based on the potential models constructed through DFT calculations and the corresponding XANES spectra, a unique heptazine chain featuring a diagonally coordinated NCuN structure is confirmed to be in closest agreement with the experimental Cu K-edge XANES spectrum (Fig. 7g). Recently, to enhance photo-self-Fenton reaction, Lian et al. creatively designed a super high-density (Ag: 22.08 wt%, Co: 1.23 wt%) Ag/Co PACs by thermal polymerizing the supramolecular precursors consisting of melamine, cyanuric acid and the mixture of citric acid with metal salts [107]. Similarly, melamine-derived 2D-CN anionic scaffolds of Na-polyheptazine and Li-polytriazine imides, when combined with NaCl or LiCl, can coordinate high-density Cu single atoms (4–5 wt%) through metal cation exchange [108]. Thereby, the thermodynamically stable multi-Cu atoms would be incorporated in the multiple exchange sites of the triangular nanopores for polymetallic interaction. Encouragingly, the incorporation of high-entropy heteroatoms can effectively minimize local symmetry, thereby destabilizing the π-electron network of graphitic carbons and preventing binding energies that are either too strong or too weak for intermediate species [109]. Using prefabricated templates derived from a mixture of annealed metal and melamine (M-g-C3N4), a movable type printing method is employed, which involves transferring thermally activated metal atoms from M-g-C3N4 to NC derived from coated dopamine hydrochloride, to synthesize a class of high-entropy single-atom catalysts (Fig. 7h) [110]. Thanks to the direct point-to-point transmission of dispersed polymetallic single atoms, PAC with up to eleven metals uniformly and stably coexisting in single support have been successfully synthesized (Fig. 7i). Besides, isolated polymetallic single atoms of Zn/La, Ni/Fe, and Ni/Cu, dispersed on melamine or dicyandiamide, have been constructed on 2D supports derived from another N/C resource complex, exhibiting high catalytic activity [111–113]. Different choices of supports or methods may induce various configurations. Wu et al. reported a soft template-directed interlayer confinement approach to confine Fe and Co ions between a self-assembled lamellar micelle formed by perfluorotetradecanoic acid and stearic acid, and an outer layer coated with polypyrrole [114]. After pyrolysis, 2D PACs anchored with Fe and Co bimetallic atoms, maintained at a distance of ∼0.5 nm, are presented. In addition, utilizing vacancies created by the continuous volatilization of Zn atoms during the calcination process, a dynamic synthetic strategy is employed to stabilize Zn SAs and capture Cu SAs, achieving a high total metal content of 7.11 wt% [115]. Interestingly, an ingenious ‘3D in 2D’ carbon nanosheet decorated with Fe and V SAs is derived from the electrostatic interaction between surface-modified silica nanospheres and Fe ions, as well as the laminar structure induced by V ions [116]. As the equally important 2D substrate, transition metal sulfides such as MoS2 [117] and transition metal oxides such as TiO2 [118], NiO [119], and CeO2 [120] have also displayed promising potential in the metal-support interaction. In order to avert the instability of isolated metal atoms on high-temperature treatment, 2D polyphthalocyanine organic frameworks are developed via low-temperature solid-phase polymerization [111], electrochemical reduction [115], and ion exchange under microwave conditions [121]. Due to limitations in geometry and pore structure, 2D supports still require further research into high-precision technologies in order to meet application requirements. 3.3.3 3D supports 3D materials, which possess not only a high surface area but also a well-defined porous structure and mechanical robustness, have garnered extensive attention in the development of versatile PACs. Standing out from the state-of-the-art 3D substrates, spatially confined MOF precursors possess atomically dispersed coordination nodes and adjustable pore or cage size, which may provide an ideal environment to anchor abundant single atom sites and avoid agglomeration. In general, metal cations can be introduced in the ZIF skeleton through a competitive complexation process [122]. To explore the synergistic catalytic mechanism of atomic dispersed PACs, the Cu/Zn-NC is derived from the pyrolysis of Cu2+, Zn2+and 2-methylimidazole ligand self-assembled CuZn-ZIF precursor (Fig. 7j). Inspired by a spatial confinement strategy, Li et al. synthesized Fe-N4/Pt-N4@NC stemmed from the cages of ZIF8s (11.6 Å) in situ encapsulating Fe(acac)3 (9.7 Å) and Pt(acac)2 (10.0 Å) to ensure uniform distribution during pyrolysis [122]. Additionally, the functional modification of the ZIF surface would be a useful strategy to optimize PACs. For instance, an interfacial assembly strategy employing ZIF-8@ZIF-67 was utilized to construct a nanocage structure encapsulated within a porous shell. Notably, this structure, denoted as Fe/Co-N x , exhibits a high atomic loading of 2.4 wt% Fe and 5.5 wt% Co [123]. Recently, Lou and colleagues employed tannic acid-chelated ZIF-8 to perform Co cation exchange and ligand exchange procedures, thereby meticulously constructing hollow nanoboxes adorned with O-coordinated Zn/Co PACs [124]. Similar 3D structures can also be obtained through chemical etching and coordination by phytic acid [125]. A novel multi-scaled Cu-Co/NC material, featuring concave interior cavities, has been innovatively designed through the strategic integration of polymetallic MOF with Na2CO3, resorcinol, formaldehyde, and melamine, followed by polymerization and annealing processes [126]. Especially, combined with COFs, the unique COF@MOF core–shell framework as an ideal template can not only mitigate MOF aggregation and structural collapse but also remain more highly active N/O/Zn atoms during pyrolysis [127]. Besides, other templates such as NaCl [128], polystyrene spheres [129] or polyvinylpyrrolidone [130,131] can be integrated with ZIF-8 for polymetallic single-atom anchored 3D porous supports. Unlike MOF-based synthesis, a supracrystal-based synthetic methodology is presented, transitioning from oleic-acid-capped Mn0.43Fe2.57O4 nanocrystals to an atomically dispersed Mn-Fe ordered mesoporous graphitic structure. This approach ensures comprehensive accessibility to active sites [132]. Recently, a series of polymetallic atoms supported on modularly assembled hierarchical USY zeolites have been developed through acid-base coordination chemistry and sterically confined solid-state chemistry, achieving superior metal-support interactions [125]. Employing 2-methylimidazolate as the bridging ligand to interconnect metals, the Cu-M PACs (with M = Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) exhibit a metal loading that is double that of SACs (Fig. 7k). The XPS results confirm the presence of Cu species in all samples with an oxidation state of +2, specifically identifying Cu2+-meIm-M2+ dual atom sites (Fig. 7l). To investigate the metal constituents within the poly-atomic structures, matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF)/time-of-flight mass spectrometry (TOF-MS) is employed to differentiate the various metal nuclearities and elemental compositions (Fig. 7m). By utilizing SiO2 spheres as a rigid template, o-phenylenediamine undergoes polymerization with potassium ferricyanide and potassium cobalticyanide, ultimately transforming into a hierarchical porous carbon skeleton loaded with 3.1 wt% Fe and 3.3 wt% Co following carbonization and acid etching processes [133]. Due to the abundance of functional groups, a novel biomass hydrogel template can be synthesized by mixing gelatin with a copper(II)/iron(II)-phenanthroline complex and SiO2 nanoparticles. This template, upon carbonization, transforms into a carbon aerogel loaded with 3.1 wt% Fe and 3.3 wt% Co, with Fe/Cu sites dispersed at a distance of approximately 5.1 Å [134]. Besides, based on a microemulsion-co-precipitation reaction, a reverse-micelle assembly-pyrolysis strategy is presented for a typical open hollow sphere with a hierarchical porous structure to embed Co/Fe single atoms [135]. From the foregoing, coplanar discrete PACs, as the most straightforward and prevalent type with relatively less stringent conditions, have been systematically investigated on supports of various dimensions. Thus, an effective approach to building high-density PACs is to choose proper support materials such as CNTs, g-C3N4, or MOFs with abundant trapping sites. Moreover, modifying and extending the current materials would offer promising improvements for achieving enhanced metal coordination and an optimal ultimate structure. 3.4 Coplanar type-mixed PACs (Type I + II, I + III) This kind of PAC, as a mixture of the above types, can be subdivided into two major categories Type I + II (combined with N-bridged and metal bond) and Type I + III (cooperated between single-atom and poly-atom sites). Type-mixed PACs can integrate diverse advantages through various association methods, thereby altering the electron distribution and chemical state of polymetallic active centers. Originating from the poly-metal interaction with specific geometric structures and synergistic effect, many type-mixed PACs have been designed and extensively studied for their excellent performance and unique mechanisms. 3.4.1 Type I + II Utilizing direct coordination among poly-metal atoms and shared N-bridge connections, the PACs are capable of constructing structures that exhibit enhanced thermodynamic stability and energetic favorability. Analogous to the preparation methods employed for other types of catalysts mentioned above, the strategy of preselecting metal precursors is once again applicable for the synthesis of precisely targeted PACs structures. For example, the well-defined AgN3-AgN3 active sites are constructed through the pyrolysis of prefabricated binuclear Ag aromatic molecule complexes anchored on graphene [136]. Recently, a bonded Fe DAC as Fe2N6C8O2 configuration was developed through one-step carbonization of a preselected COF with bimetallic Fe chelation sites [137]. Notably, the dynamic structural evolution of Fe coordination within the COF, transitioning from FeOFe to FeO x , Fe NPs, and ultimately to coupled Fe dual atoms, is illustrated during thermal activation (Fig. 8 a). For selective hydrogenation and epoxidation, Li et al. designed Pt2/mpg-C3N4, which was derived from a combination of (ethylenediamine) iodoplatinum(II) dimer dinitrate (as the dual-atomic Pt precursor) and mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (as the substrate) [138]. Similarly, to synthesize N/P co-coordinated FeCo PACs, Shui and co-workers chose the C34H28Cl2CoFeP2 molecule as the precursors (Fig. 8b) [139]. Owing to the combined effects of strong metal bonding and unique heteroatom bridging, the PACs exhibit significant alterations in electronic localization and spin polarization, thereby enhancing their adsorption capabilities and catalytic performance. Additionally, various types of PACs such as Fe-Mn-N-C [140], PtNiN5O/ZrO2@C [141], and FeCu-NC [142] are respectively designed from MOF-based precursors of Pt@UiO-66-NH2(Ni), poly-metal-ZIFs and IISERP-MOF27, respectively. Besides, customized ligands are also utilized for constructing desired structures. To attain high-density metal loading on N-doped graphene (NG), Zeng et al. employed a complex of L-alanine and melamine with Ni(II) and Fe(II) acetates to synthesize NiFe PACs, achieving a metal loading of 4.05 wt% Ni and 3.24 wt% Fe through a process involving pyrolysis, HCl etching, and reannealing (Fig. 8c) [143]. By virtue of XAS measurements, apart from the FeN and NiN scattering paths observed at approximately 1.5 Å, the additional peak observed in the range of 2.2–2.5 Å can be attributed to the FeNi bond (Fig. 8d, e). In the same way, Sun et al. successfully repeated this preparation and verified a similar configuration by WT-EXAFS analysis [144]. Obviously, the contour plots exhibit two distinct WT signals at approximately 3.8 Å and 5.0 Å (Fig. 8f, g), suggesting the coexistence of metalN and FeNi bonds. Not limited to carbon-based supports, the use of templates such as PDA-coated ZnO [145], polypyrrole-coated MnO2 [146], and 1,10-phenanthroline-mixed Mg(OH)2 [147,148] allows for the construction of multi-connected polymetallic atoms embedded within N-doped carbon materials. 3.4.2 Type I + III Different from the general studies that primarily focus on single systems with poly-atom configurations, this type of PAC integrates single atoms and dimer or low-nuclearity atom-dispersed cluster sites into a single system. By combining the advantages of single and polynary atoms, the synergistic coupling of the two types of active sites has the potential to achieve the desired catalytic performance through the regulation of their electronic structures and intermediate electronic states. More importantly, the synergism from asymmetric charge distributions and co-adsorption modes may break the limitations of activation of reactants or intermediates, making the PACs more potential and promising in the field of catalysis [149]. Wei et al. developed a 'heteroatom modulator approach' specifically for MOFs, which involves the strategic incorporation of second metal ions (Zn/Co) into Fe-complexes, resulting in the loading of a series of trinuclear complexes within the MOF [150]. The dominant presence of Fe nanoclusters is observed when utilizing solely the Fe3 (FeIII 2FeII) complex, due to its ability to thermally transform from unstable trimers into clusters (Fig. 8h). Intriguingly, when a thermally removable Zn atom replaces the FeII ion in the Fe3 complex, only Fe dimers are observed. This observation suggests the evaporation of Zn metal and the formation of a more stable metal species, namely Fe2-N6. Furthermore, it can form single Co atoms and dual Fe atoms separately embedded within an N-doped carbon layer, indicating the successful extension of the accurate synthesis strategy and its guiding implications at the atomic scale [151]. Recently, Huang et al. proposed a ternary-atomic engineering strategy to purposefully construct the neighboring NiN4 single-metal-atom and Fe2N5 dual-metal-atoms on the N-doped hollow carbon sphere via double-solvents impregnation and additional N ligand method [152]. The HAADF-STEM images and extracted EELS spectra clearly illustrate the coexistence of Ni SA and Fe dimer and the atomic distance of FeFe and Fe2 Ni (Fig. 8i, j), which may be the main identifying characteristics of this type. Subsequently, to enhance the catalytic performance and stability of Fe-N4 configurations, Wang et al. designed M4 atomic clusters (ACs)-modified Fe-N4 sites embedded within an N-doped carbon matrix [153]. The controllable preparation of atomically dispersed Fe4/Fe1 or Co4/Fe1 polymetallic centers is achieved through a pre-constrained strategy involving the implantation of Fe4/Co4 molecular clusters and Fe(acac)3 precursors within ZIF-8 (Fig. 8k). This approach effectively prevents the formation of random dispersions and large nanoparticles during the pyrolysis process. Guided by DFT calculations, Qi et al. demonstrated and screened a series of M-N4 single atoms to improve the coordination environment and electronic interaction of Fe5 atomic clusters [154]. The optimum Fe5 ACs and Cu SAs decorated NC were designed through pyrolysis of composite materials composed of poly(ethylene oxide)-block-polystyrene and PDA-assembled GO. Obviously, the FT EXAFS spectra and EXAFS fitting results for the Fe K-edge exhibit a prominent peak corresponding to the FeN scattering path and a smaller peak associated with the FeFe scattering path. In contrast, only a single peak indicative of CuN scattering is observed in the Cu K-edge (Fig. 8l, m). These observations are largely consistent with the expected coordination numbers of 4.26 for FeN, 3.60 for FeFe, and 3.80 for CuN bonds, suggesting a highly controllable preparation strategy. Similarly, Guo et al. designed Pt6-AC/Cr-SA catalyst originating from anchoring triphenylphosphine coordinated Pt6 clusters on Cr-N4 sites [151]. Furthermore, many efforts have been devoted for the coupled system of metal ACs and SAs by utilizing protonated substrate [155], directly pyrolyzing NC adsorbed metal resource [8], adding additional ligand [156] and other regulatory strategy. As mentioned above, various mixed types of PACs have been also successfully prepared and characterized. Nevertheless, the recognition of acquired atomic centers and the underlying mechanism responsible for the enhanced catalytic activity remain indeterminate and elusive. Meanwhile, the controllable fabrication of well-defined type-mixed PACs remains a formidable challenge, primarily due to the high surface energy of metal atoms. 3.5 Nonplanar PACs (Type IV) Unlike planar catalysts featuring multiple metallic sites, non-coplanar PACs possessing spatially isolated or asymmetric structures can equally be employed for achieving highly efficient and selective catalytic reactions. Considering the propensity of coplanar single-atom sites to preferentially augment the adsorption and catalytic properties of specific intermediates, while potentially overlooking broader selectivity outcomes, it becomes essential to undertake a strategic spatial modulation of diverse active sites. This modulation is crucial for effectively intercepting and promoting the sequential catalysis of reaction intermediates throughout their transformation process, thereby elevating the selectivity of the catalytic reaction [20]. To achieve the dissociation of atoms in space, the construction of a Janus-distributed structure is considered an effective strategy. Typically, Qiu et al. proposed a step-by-step self-assembly strategy to allocate Ni and Fe SAs respectively on the inner or outer walls of graphene hollow nanospheres [157,158]. Illustratively, by sequentially adsorbing [Ni(CN)4]2− onto GO via electrostatic interactions and depositing FePC onto SiO2 nanospheres through π-π stacking, researchers synthesized separate-sided Ni-N4/Fe-N4 PACs. Annealing and etching treatments afforded PACs with remarkable performance in controllable selective catalysis. On this basis, the trilaminar sandwich-like configuration was further designed by the additional adsorption of Co and intercalated L-Histidine (Fig. 9 a) [19]. Such a universal strategy for spatial-separated PACs not only achieves atomic dispersion but also guarantees threefold enhancement of metal loading (up to 21.24 wt%). Intriguingly, Wu et al. introduced a novel yolk-shell Pd@Fe PAC, featuring harmonious Fe-N4 and Pd-N4 single-atom systems on N-doped carbon and yolk, respectively, crafted from Zr6-UiO-66-NH2/PdCl2 and SiO2/Fe polymer (Fig. 9b) [159]. The core–shell structure and the element distribution of segregated Fe and Pt SAs are clearly demonstrated via the HAADF-STEM image and the energy-dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping (Fig. 9c–e). Similarly, SiO2 was sequentially employed as a hard template twice and immersed in formamide solutions containing distinct metal precursors, a double-shelled structure with isolated metal sites was designed. This effectively mitigates the migration and aggregation of polynary metal atoms [160]. Besides, the construction of lamellar structure also shows promise in nonplanar ploy-atom catalysis. To precisely manipulate coordination environments and elevate the atomic-scale density of Fe-N-C motifs, an axial O modifier is utilized to forge FeOFe bridge bonds, thereby stably chelating dual-layered Fe-N4 sites [161]. Specifically, the in-situ composite resorcinol–formaldehyde resin is employed to link Fe with oxygen functional groups and construct the layered structure via a two-step pyrolysis process. The immobilization of a homogenous single-atom catalyst on a heterogenous metal-N x functional carbon matrix is expected to fabricate PACs electrocatalysts. The precise immobilization of dual single Co atomic sites within cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPC) is achieved through the utilization of π-π and Co-Co interactions, employing Co-N3 site-modified NC [162]. This approach facilitates the controlled adjustment of the relative abundance between the two distinct sites, thereby exposing more active sites. Sun et al. proposed the dual-atom Fe by the face-to-face self-assembly method of transforming molecular FePc into nanorod-like architectures under microwave irradiation [163]. The stacking and parallel structure with an appropriate distance between adjacent Fe atoms as 4.92 Å is confirmed (Fig. 9f), which may improve the way of adsorption and catalysis. Furtherly, the EXAFS spectra not only demonstrate the maintenance of atomically dispersed Fe atoms but also indicate the existence of dual-atom Fe sites with strong FeFe interactions (Fig. 9g). In similar, to break the 2D confinement effect, Wang et al. developed the axial dual atomic sites by the auxiliary of NaCl for metal phthalocyanine molecules self-assembling to build 3D layer-stacked graphene on 2D plane [164]. The resultant 3D confinement effect not only augments axial diatomic sites but also mitigates out-of-plane metal atom motility, thereby enhancing the overall structural integrity and catalytic stability (Fig. 9h). The pristine MOFs with flexible self-adaptive structures and tailorable properties enable the facile separation of polymetallic atom sites. For instance, the paired Cu and Ni sites in their respective single-atom forms are incorporated into robust MOFs-808 [165]. Intriguingly, the flexible spatial configurations of the Cu/Ni pairs can evolve continuously with the variable intermediates in a self-adaptive manner during the multistep catalytic reaction, which presents much better adsorption selectivity and stabilization than the fixed metal sites (Fig. 9i). Considering the post-synthetic modification approach, the high active di-tin (IV) sites are integrated into functional MOFs through a universal “ship-in-a-bottle” strategy [166]. Thereby, the dual Sn atom sites coordinated with O atoms are seamlessly integrated into adjacent Zr nodes within NU-1000, exhibiting a remarkable synergistic effect stemming from the spatially dominant bridging mode. As a functional ligand, MOFs can combine molecular tunability for spatial separation and cooperation of single-atom sites. Similarly, adopting a post-synthetic method, Shang et al. prepared the multivariate porphyrin-based MOFs by inserting a series of metal atoms into porphyrin ring centers [167]. Such a unique hierarchical structure not only increases the exposed active sites but also enhanced the collaborated adsorption and conversion for pivotal reaction intermediates (Fig. 9j). Furthermore, leveraging the confinement effect and flexible substrate effect, metal nodes anchored on spatially distributed organic linkers of MOFs have been extensively fabricated and applied in sustainable catalysis [11,168,169]. As the novel modulation strategy, the “single-atom to single-atom” grafting or deposition may comprehensively ameliorate the polymetallic interaction. Therefore, Zeng et al. utilized Fe single atoms as the foundation and relied on point-to-point fixation and in-situ thermal reduction of Pt precursors to synthesize Pt-grafted Fe PACs with bridging O molecules [170]. Therein, Pt@Fe-N-C exhibits an excellent and stable catalytic activity owing to the protection of PtO cap and significant synergy through the unique dangling bond structure (Fig. 9k). Similarly, Sun et al. also developed the PACs with axial Au atom anchored on Co single-atom site [171]. Relying on the DFT calculation and the Co K-edge XANES spectra, the FDMNES codes are adopted to verify the local structure consistent with the experimental result, implying this specific structure (Fig. 9l). Under different conditions (250 °C with O2 and 150 °C with O3), the stepwise ALD technique can also be employed to design the bottom-up distribution of supported atomically precise Pt dimers [172]. Thus, a Pt2O6 chain structure with O atoms alternating between the terminal and bridge positions is constructed and further validate the distance and tilted angle (Fig. 9m). Additionally, by situating W within [WO4] tetrahedra and Mo within distorted [MoO6] octahedra, an O-coordinated W/Mo hetero dimer is synthesized on NG via a hydrothermal reaction followed by a CVD process [173]. The wrinkles in NG may cause the coaxial alignment of W and Mo atoms to deviate from parallelism with the plane, resulting in variations in the W/Mo diatomic distance. These variations can be visualized through different angles of metal sites observed in HAADF images (Fig. 9n). Such a distinctive WOMoOC configuration with strong covalent interactions harvests excellent catalytic activity and high stability. As previously mentioned, a significant innovation lies in the construction of nonplanar PACs, which breaks the in-plane constraint of polymetallic atomic configurations and maximizes the utilization of metal atom active sites and substrate conditions. The excellent spatial structure effect and the change of adsorption modes are presented for enhanced affinity and selectivity. In future research, designing the special distributed poly-atom sites may provide another way to improve the intrinsic activity of PACs. In this chapter, we comprehensively summarize and analyze the controllable fabrication and precise recognition of state-of-the-art PACs. Each PAC with unique geometric and electronic modifications can be designed and explored for optimum activation and selectivity during diverse catalytic reactions. Thereby, the distinct cooperative modes and charge redistribution between polymetallic atoms are regarded as the key factors to affect the activity and stability of PACs. In addition, some specific means have been discovered and classified, which may be expected to guide the design of target PACs (Table 1 ). Even though, it is still insufficient to develop effective strategies for the desired microenvironment regulation and advanced characterization methods of PACs. Especially, based on the current technologies, how to overcome the not uniform distribution and relatively low content as well as the laborious identification of the real polymetallic active sites still remains a challenge and needs further exploration. 4 Versatile interaction of PACs The most prominent feature of PACs is multi-metal-atom interaction. Many studies have attempted to study the controllable formation and coordination strategy for polynary atom sites. Under the metal–metal interaction in PACs, the evident change of chemical states and electronic structures induced by electron redistribution is expected to improve the catalytic performance. Typically, with the entropy increase of SA active sites, the degree of disorder is elevated, which is prone to breaking the M-N4 symmetric electronic structure [186]. Chen et al. designed the asymmetric ZnCoFe trimetallic atom catalysts, where Co acts the main active site, Fe is a co-catalytic site and Zn is responsible for regulating electronic structures [187]. The ZnCoFe PACs with significant synergetic effects show better ORR performance than that of ZnCo DACs and Co SACs. However, it has not always been like this. As demonstrated by Guo et al., despite the interaction between Pt and Mo SA sites, the promotional effect was more prominent on the low-nuclearity Pt PAs than the smaller SAs and bigger nanoclusters [67]. Therefore, some other effects also play an important role in PAC activity. Herein, we will discuss from the following perspectives of metal–metal bonding interaction, coordination and distance effect, metal-substrate interaction and geometry regulation effect. 4.1 Metal-metal interacting effect As one of the PAC characteristics, the formation of metal–metal bonding will induce enhanced metal interactions. Among them, metal–metal bonds formed at polymetallic sites can improve the electron structure distribution and spin–orbit coupling of polymetallic atoms through charge transfer [188]. For instance, owing to both Co/CuN coordination and CoCu coordination, the CoCu-DASC catalyst shows large differences in the electronic structure, compared with Co-SAC and Cu-SAC catalysts [189]. Within this context, the apparent negative charges present between the Co and Cu atoms clearly demonstrate the electronic interaction occurring between the polymetallic sites, facilitated by the formation of CoCu bonds. The synergistic effect from this metal–metal bonding structure generates a significant impact on catalytic activity and selectivity. As shown in Fig. 10 a, the valence charge density differences of NiN4 C, ZnN4 C and NiZnN6 C sites were calculated [60]. The charge calculation results plainly reveal that the Ni and Zn in NiZnN6 C harvest 0.15 and 0.06 more electrons than Ni in NiN4 C and Zn in ZnN4 C, respectively. Meanwhile, the XPS spectra of Ni 2p and Zn 2p in NiZnN6 C show negative shifts of 0.50 and 0.18 eV, suggestive of the metal bonding effect for charge polarization. It can be attributed to strong metal properties in NiZnN6 C for facilitating efficient electron acquisition via ZnCo bonds, significantly enhance the synergistic effect of PACs. Furtherly, Zhang et al. researched and compared the difference between isolated diatomic FeNi electrocatalyst (I-FeNi-DASC) and the diatomic electrocatalyst with bonded FeNi pairs (B-FeNi-DASC) [47]. Compared with I-FeNi-DASC, the partial density of states (PDOS) of 3d orbitals in B-FeNi-DASC present the increased electronic states toward the Fermi level (Fig. 10b). As for the differential charge density maps, a more obvious charge transfer is observed on FeNiN6 sites of B-FeNi-DASC than FeN4 and NiN4 sites of I-FeNi-DASC (Fig. 10c). Therefore, the bonded FeNi diatomic structure derived electron localization around the active sites is prone to optimize the adsorption and activation for the key intermediates. To be specific, the reactions are dominated by CO2RR to CO on Ni-SAC and NO3RR to NH3 on Fe-SAC, which cause low efficiencies and yield rates of urea since a unilateral scarcity of intermediate species. In contrast, the I-FeNi-DASC with isolated Fe and Ni sites exhibits excellent responses to both CO2RR and NO3RR. At –1.5 V, the faradaic efficiencies (FEs) for CO2RR to CO and NO3RR to NH3 are 82.5% and 78.9%, respectively (Fig. 10d), indicating robust activity in both reactions. Additionally, DFT calculations verify that the diatomic Ni2 N3 structure in Ni2-NCNT enhances catalytic activity by reducing the reaction-free energy through the creation of a bridged *COOH intermediate at the Ni2 catalytic site (Fig. 10e, f) [31]. In summary, by altering the combination of the two metals within DASCs, various bonding strengths can be tailored, thereby achieving different binding energies between the DASCs and intermediates involved in CO2RR or other relevant reactions. Equally important, the metal–metal bonds in PACs can be classified as nonpolar and polar bonds, which derive from the homo- and hetero-polymetallic atomic configuration [22]. In contrast to homonuclear PACs, which feature identical central metal atoms and symmetric charge distribution, heteronuclear PACs exhibit structural deformation and asymmetric charge density, depending on the nature of the meta–metal bonding. Thus, the different electronic and structural properties of PACs may lead to unanticipated catalytic performance. For instance, theoretically, the intermediate atoms absorbed on symmetrical homonuclear DAC sites exhibit equal electron scattering, which impedes CC coupling pathways (Fig. 10g). Comparatively, due to the distinct electronegativity and gradient orbital coupling at heteroatoms, intermediates on heteronuclear DACs exhibit asymmetric charge distributions (Fig. 10h, i). This suppresses repulsive molecular interactions and enhances the collision probability for coupling adjacent intermediates to form C2+ products [190]. Song et al. revealed that the ZnCoN4O2/CN dual-core single-atom catalyst excels in facilitating Li+ transport, enhancing Li2S diffusion and catalyzing sulfur conversion, compared to homonuclear diatomic catalysts [191]. Therefore, heteronuclear DACs that integrate the nature of two different metals can result in superior catalytic performance. Furthermore, the d-band coordination between heteronuclear metals enables flexible adjustment of active sites and lowering of the energy barrier in certain catalytic reactions. So far, many breakthroughs have been achieved in synthesis and application for the specific type of PACs. The research findings by Zhang et al. revealed that the FeO bond length of *NO3 on Fe/Fe measures 1.823 Å, whereas the CuO bond length of *NO3 on Cu/Cu is 1.945 Å, indicating a stronger interaction of Fe with the intermediate compared to Cu (Fig. 10j). From a d-band center perspective, this suggests that Fe's three-dimensional orbital position is higher than that of Cu, potentially resulting in stronger adsorption of most intermediates. Other pertinent theoretical findings corroborate that Fe/Cu-HNG can lower the energy barrier for NO3 −RR and activate NO molecules, thereby enhancing both the yield and selectivity of NH3 (Fig. 10k, l). Moreover, it has been demonstrated that d-p orbital coupling between hetero-atomic DAC species can enhance catalytic activity. Specifically, Fe-Ni-NG features hetero-diatomic Fe-Ni sites that effectively immobilize LiPSs and reduce the reaction barrier through d-p orbital hybridization [65]. Additionally, by computing the formation energies of Cu/Mn, Ni/Mn, and Ni/Fe DMSCs and comparing them to the energies of Cu/Cu, Mn/Mn, Fe/Fe, and Ni/Ni DMSCs, researchers evaluated the likelihood of producing heteronuclear active sites versus homonuclear ones. Encouragingly, researchers have discovered that all heteronuclear DMSCs exhibit a lower formation energy compared to their homonuclear counterparts. This suggests that heteronuclear active sites are more feasible to produce experimentally [192]. In addition to bimetallic monatomic catalysts, hetero-trimetallic atom catalysts demonstrate exceptional catalytic activity owing to their distinctive active site structures. DFT calculations reveal that among them, the Co atom serves as the active site, as it is the most optimal intermediate for oxygen binding. Furthermore, the Zn site exhibits strong adsorption of OH*, which boosts the OER activity. Additionally, the presence of a Fe atom at the ZnN3CoN3FeN2S site leads to a reduction in the d-band center of the Co atom, subsequently weakening the CoO binding energy and enhancing the catalytic performance of the material. As a result, the synthesized ZnCoFe-TAC/SNC has excellent ORR and OER properties, superior to other monometallic or bimetallic SA catalysts [187]. Jia et al. developed a novel asymmetric polyatomic catalyst known as NiCo-TiO2. This catalyst breaks symmetry and facilitates charge transfer through metal bonding [193]. However, incorporating asymmetric dual-atom sites complicates the structure, resulting in a lack of comprehensive understanding regarding the inter-metal interactions and the underlying catalytic mechanism. In conclusion, metal–metal interactions play a crucial role in modulating the atomic structure, local coordination, and electronic properties of PACs, thereby influencing their catalytic behavior. Specifically, metal–metal interaction serves as one of the pivotal factors in regulating the catalytic performance of PACs. By finely tuning the intrinsic properties of the catalyst, it profoundly influences its catalytic behavior, encompassing various aspects such as catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability. 4.2 Coordination and distance effect The activity of PACs largely depends on the coordination environment of their metal center species, which includes both metal and non-metal coordination elements, as well as atomic distances (both bonded and non-bonded interactions). These factors play a crucial role in the catalytic reactivity due to the presence of strong metal-support interactions (SMSIs). For the simple SACs, various strategies, including geometric defect generation [194], coordination number variation [195], and heteroatom introduction [196] have been employed to regulate the coordination environment of SACs. In this context, the introduction of the Cl ligand, which has a low electronegativity, into FeN4Cl serves to induce d-band delocalization of the central Fe atoms. This optimization helps to adjust the adsorption-free energy of the *OOH/*OH intermediates, thereby enhancing the ORR processes [197]. Also, the S element doping into unsymmetrical Cu-S1N3 configuration can contribute to the stable adsorption toward OOH* intermediates to accelerate conversion of O2 to H2O [198]. Pertaining to the complex PACs, both homonuclear (e.g., Co2N5/C, Cu2C2N, and Mn2-Pc) [199–201] and heteronuclear (Zn, Co-N x -C-S y , FeCoN x /C, and FeNi SAs/NC) [53,202] DACs have been put forward. The introduction of adjacent metal site can not only provide greater metal-support interactions, but also can affect the electronic structures and orbital interactions via molecular asymmetry to facilitate catalytic performance [203]. For instance, homonuclear DACs (such as Mn-, Fe-, and Co-based DACs) with three-N coordination were found to exhibit larger spin magnetic moments compared to those with a four-N coordination cis-configuration. This larger magnetic moment facilitates stronger adsorption affinity towards O intermediate species (Fig. 11 a, b) [203]. The DACs featuring 2N-bridged (Fe-Ni)N6 are highly likely to exhibit greater catalytic activity and selectivity than the bare FeN4 or NiN4 sites. This is due to the synergistic effect of the metal and N coordination, which enables them to achieve optimal desorption of *COOH and *CO compared to single-metal sites (Fig. 11c–e) [80]. Researchers further discovered that the interaction between neighboring single atoms can significantly impact catalytic performance when compared to isolated atoms. This interaction optimizes the adsorption of intermediates and influences the product distribution consequently. Generally speaking, when the distance between Fe and M is less than 15 Å, the metal atom can significantly influence the catalytic activity of the Fe sites. Conversely, if the distance exceeds 15 Å, the system functions as a SAC. In this respect, the interaction between the π* orbital of the catalytic intermediate species and the d orbitals of the Fe active sites leads to variations in both the d-orbital splitting and the electron delocalization, transitioning from the low-spin dxy and dyz orbitals to the high-spin d x 2 - y 2 state of Fe [204]. The non-bonding interaction between counterpart metals can synergistically adjust the electronic properties and catalytic activity of the Fe active site, weakening the OH* adsorption to facilitate the 4e− ORR process. This effect can be attributed to the high Bader charge transfer coupled with the high spin density at the Fe site, which promotes the 4e− ORR [205]. The orbital coupling interaction between the two metal centers has been shown to overcome the scaling relationship limit, thereby facilitating electrochemical reactions. Additionally, non-bonding interactions can also have a significant impact on their catalytic activity [205]. Based on a systematic exploration of catalyst limitations, the researcher screened different transition metal atoms (M = Co, Pt, Fe, Ni) in nitrogen-doped graphene. Subsequently, ORR scaling relations were established, and the catalytic activity was plotted on a volcano plot (Fig. 11f). It reveals the local pore distortion induced by adjacent metal atom is sufficient to alter overpotentials by 1/10 V to accelerate ORR performance [194]. The metal distance can be tuned by varying N coordination during the Fenton-like reaction process. After the Fe atoms (with a Fe1-Fe1 distance of less than 4 Å) are saturated with PMS, Fe-N-C-PMS* complexes form on Fe sites where the Fe1-Fe1 distance is 4–5 Å. These complexes can coordinate with FeII-N4 to form an inter-complex, which exhibits enhanced charge transfer and results in the production of FeIV O. This inter-complex enables high PMS adsorption, exhibits small free energy changes, has wide pH tolerance, and possesses high oxidation capacity (Fig. 11g, h) [99]. The introduction of asymmetric dual-atom catalysts (such as NiCu DACs), with an inter-metal distance threshold of approximately 5.3 Å between the Ni-N4 and Cu-N4 moieties, has been demonstrated to effectively regulate electronics and enhance the selectivity and activity of the CO2 reduction reaction (Fig. 11i–k) [113]. Bonding interaction is another crucial strategy in the spacing enhancement effect of diatomic catalysts [206]. Chen et al. highlight the pivotal role of bridging OO bond in regulating metal distances and geometries of Fe2 and Cu2 catalysts. They reveal that the reactivity of the bridging O atom contributes to diverse pathways for OO bond formation in both Cu2 and Fe2 catalysts. A comparison between Cu2 and Fe2 catalysts demonstrates that the different bimetallic cores yield varying reactivity of the high-valent M-O-M species, leading to distinct OO bonding pathways. This work emphasizes the importance of considering the geometric aspects of catalysts induced by bond interactions, and offers valuable insights into the rational design of water oxidation catalysts (Fig. 11l, m) [207]. Bonding interactions can not only manipulate the atomic metal distance by varying the catalytic geometry, but they can also be influenced by doping with heteroatoms to achieve the desired adsorption and catalytic performance. Zhong and co-workers designed three Ni2 sites (Ni2-N7, Ni2-N5C2, Ni2-N3C4) by pyrolysis of dinuclear nickel complex with dicyandiamide and carbon black at 900 °C [70]. Among them, single N-bridged Ni2-N3C4 with about 3.1 Å displays more proper binding energy to COOH* and CO* intermediates than the other two structures. This optimal characteristic of maintaining a suitable atomic distance through heteroatom-bridged PACs results in special regulation of the electronic structure at the Ni-N-Ni sites. Accordingly, the coordination and distance effects in PACs significantly impact their catalytic performance by influencing the active site configuration, interaction strength with reactants, and charge transfer dynamics, thereby affecting catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability. 4.3 Metal-substrate interacting effect The metal-substrate interaction plays an important role in determining the electronic properties of PACs, thus affecting the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Specifically, the electronic properties of PACs can be greatly determined by modulating the charge transfer between the metal atoms and the support. In previous studies, Jiang et al. modified the foundational structure of PACs using stress-induced interface assembly, achieving the transition from solid nanopolyhedra to ultra-thin nanocages. Surface XPS analysis reveals that the metal content of hollow FeCo-NHC is significantly higher compared to solid FeCo-NC (6.9 wt% versus 3.0 wt%) (Fig. 12 a). In cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements, the reduction peak corresponding to NO2- for FeCo-NCH is notably larger than that observed for FeCo-NC (Fig. 12b). This enhancement can be attributed to the porous shell structure and tens of nanometers of hollow interior in FeCo-NCH, facilitating increased active sites and improved metal utilization (Fig. 12c) [123]. Another intriguing study demonstrates that PACs with high surface free energy offer effective protection against performance degradation, corrosion, and thermodynamically driven atom aggregation, even in challenging reaction environments characterized by spatial constraints. Using laser molecular beam epitaxy (LMBE) and subsequent self-bending treatment, single atoms of Ni and Fe (SAs) were confined simultaneously to two adjacent layers of MoS2 (NiFe@MoS2 with interlayer restriction). The findings indicate that this interlayer confinement optimizes the dissociation capability of the HOH bond, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity (Fig. 12d, e) [208]. Furthermore, the synergistic interaction between metal atoms and the support material can significantly influence electrocatalytic activity. Considering the easily modulated oxygen vacancy on the CeO2 surface and its robust chemical stability, Wang et al. propose that CeO2-x nanorods, featuring abundant oxygen vacancies and favorable axial charge transfer, represent promising supports for atom anchoring. By incorporating Cu and Sn atoms onto CeO2-x (CuSn/CeO2-x), they developed an electrocatalyst combining p-block and d-block elements.
