CuSn/CeO2-x exhibited remarkable performance in formic acid oxidation, achieving partial current densities of 65.4 and 216.8 mA cm−2 in H-cells and flow cells at −1.2 V vs. RHE, respectively. The ICOHP analysis indicated stronger CuO and SnO bonds (ICOHP = 1.64/4.27) compared to CuSn/CeO2 (ICOHP = 1.16/3.97), underscoring the enhanced bond strengths on CeO x and emphasizing the pivotal role of oxygen vacancies in stabilizing anchored atoms (Fig. 12f, g) [120]. Apart from the metal matrix, the two-dimensional CN substrate exhibits numerous advantages, including the regulation of electronic structures, high chemical stability, an extensive surface area, and exceptional photocatalytic properties. These attributes collectively position the CN substrate as a dynamic and evolving platform for modifications. A comprehensive study has been conducted to investigate the uniform dispersion of high-density monatomic Cu groups into nanoscale pores appended with N within the two-dimensional CN matrices. Among them, optimized Cu-PTI nanocrystalline structures maximize the performance of electrochemical CO2 reduction to CH4, achieving a Faraday efficiency (FECH4) of approximately 68% and a high bias current density of 348 mA cm−2 at a low potential of −0.84 V, surpassing state-of-the-art catalysts (Fig. 12h, i) [108]. The fabrication of densely distributed M-N x PACs and precise microenvironmental control are crucial for enhancing catalytic performance. Wei et al. discovered that specific metal-carrier interactions alter the OER activity of Ir monomers. Their studies reveal that the strong interaction between Ir atoms and the carrier induces active site modulation at precise locations, effectively enhancing the adsorption strength of intermediates and thereby optimizing Ir site activity over Ni sites [209]. Furthermore, in recent researches, Li and colleagues have developed a 2D/2D Ru-Co DAS/NiO heterostructure, in which the synergistic effect between the multimetallic Ru and Co sites and the Ni sites on the support promotes the urea oxidation reaction [119]. Song and co-workers have demonstrated that utilizing the electronic metal-support interaction (EMSI) between noble metals and layered double hydroxides (LDH) to regulate the d-orbital structure of the noble metals is an effective strategy for tuning the HER [210]. The proximity of metal centers can promote synergistic 'co-catalysis' between the metal and substrate, altering reaction pathways and enhancing efficiency. In summary, the interaction between PACs and the substrate is a complex and multifaceted phenomenon that can profoundly affect the catalytic activity, selectivity, and durability of the catalyst. By carefully engineering this interaction, researchers can optimize the performance of catalytic systems for various applications, such as fuel cells, electrochemical reactions, and environmental remediation. 4.4 Geometry regulation effect In addition to the above characteristics, the diverse geometries of PACs also influence their catalytic activity. Diverse atoms undergo unconstrained surface collisions, resulting in the stochastic formation of PACs and consequently low yields. To address this issue, certain studies have developed stratified substrates that enable the segregated yet interactive arrangement of diverse single atoms within the catalyst. This approach fosters enhanced catalytic efficiency. For instance, the non-precious metal CoN4-C-NiN4-C-FeN4 ternary monatomic catalyst exemplifies the integration of three layers of monatomic atoms, facilitating robust electron transfer. The interlayer of Ni simultaneously provides electrons to both Fe and Co, thus augmenting the catalytic activities in ORR, OER, and HER through a mechanism characterized by 'site-selective host–guest interactions'. Among them, one of the approaches entails the integration of three distinct metal species, each possessing unique inherent activities, to establish a tri-directional catalytic pathway that facilitates competitive adsorption. In this configuration, each metal species serves as a host, presenting three potential catalytic functionalities. Conversely, diverse heterogeneous metal interfaces exhibit a synergistic effect in modulating the electronic properties of individual metals, thereby effectively addressing the activity and selectivity constraints that are often encountered with primary and secondary metals [19]. Electron density analysis reveals that in ternary metal single-atom catalysts (TSAs), the Bader charge of Fe decreases to +0.91|e|, Co decreases to +0.80|e|, and Ni increases to +0.86|e| (Fig. 13 a), indicating predominant interatomic electron transfer from Ni to Fe and Co. Furthermore, the transition from SAs to TSAs induces anisotropic alterations in the electronic properties of the three metals, thereby optimizing the reaction pathway (Fig. 13b). Furthermore, Ren et al. designed a double-shell nanocage featuring distinct and tunable single-atom active sites (Co-N4 in the interior and Zn-N4 in the exterior), facilitating analysis and interaction among the active centers of multi-atomic catalysts (Fig. 13c). Among these, double-shell nanocages equipped with dual active sites exhibit significant advantages in sequestering soluble LiPSs and facilitating tandem sulfur conversion reactions [211]. Additionally, a layered stacking structure was implemented on the surface to securely anchor Ni and Fe atoms through defect aggregation, thereby forming axial diatomic sites. This configuration induces a three-dimensional confinement effect that minimizes the out-of-plane migration of metal atoms, ensuring robust structural stability. Theoretical calculations indicate that the charge distribution at neighboring Fe atom positions can be vertically modulated by Ni atom positions, resulting in a lowered band center. This modulation decreases the energy barrier for CO generation in CO2 electroreduction, albeit hindering the HER (Fig. 13d) [164]. Shang and colleagues developed multi-metalloporphyrin-based MOFs as efficient NO2 adsorbents, characterized by atomically dispersed dual transition metal centers serving as active adsorption sites: specifically, Ni for strong NO2 adsorption and Co for strong NO adsorption. Compared to single transition metal insertion in MOFs, the synergistic effect between hierarchically inserted Ni and Co enhances the NO2 adsorption capacity of multi metallic MOFs while maintaining high NO retention capability (Fig. 13e, f) [167]. In addition to the planar substrate, the curved catalyst substrate influenced by surface curvature, also impacts the adsorption energy of ORR intermediates during the association and deionization processes. Furthermore, the incorporation of bimetallic atoms on the surface alters the catalytic activity (Fig. 13g). The data depicted in Fig. 13h, i indicate that the adsorption energies of ΔG OOH and ΔG O/OH in the CoCo model are lower compared to those in the CoNi model at equivalent radii. This discrepancy arises from the weaker binding of OH to the NiN4 site, with adsorption energies decreasing notably with increasing radius. This reduction correlates with alterations in the electronic structure during bending phenomena [212]. Furthermore, investigations have explored the construction of Fe-Co dual-site catalysts in two configurations: stereo-Fe-Co (stereo-Fe-Co DSC) and planar Fe-Co (planar-Fe-Co DSC). Notably, the planar-Fe-Co DSC exhibits superior OER performance compared to the stereo-Fe-Co DSC configuration. The DFT calculations reveal that the synthesized catalyst adheres to a dual-site mechanism (oxide pathway mechanism) rather than the conventional adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) for OER. The planar-Fe-Co DSC facilitates the dehydrogenation of intermediates into OO species during the rate-determining step more effectively than the stereo-Fe-Co DSC. The well-defined spatial arrangement of the monatomic iron site enhances the synergistic interaction between isolated iron atoms and adjacent Co atoms, thereby significantly enhancing the electrocatalytic performance (Fig. 13j, k) [185]. Having established the diverse sources of activity within PACs, including the intricate interplay of metal–metal bond interactions, the proper coordination and distance effects, the profound influence of metal-substrate interactions, and the transformative impact of geometric effects, we now turn the focus to unraveling the underlying mechanisms that govern their catalytic prowess. Each of these active sources contributes uniquely to the overall performance of polyatomic catalysts, shaping their ability to catalyze reactions with high efficiency and selectivity. In the subsequent sections, we will embark on a meticulous mechanistic analysis, aiming to elucidate the intricate interplay and synergistic effects of these various factors, thereby providing deeper insights into the remarkable catalytic properties exhibited by PACs. 5 Mechanism PACs and SACs exhibit marked disparities in their catalytic mechanisms, which are predominantly manifested in the nature of their active sites and the modalities of reaction engagement [224]. The catalytic activity of SACs is predominantly attributed to the long-range interactions between the active atoms and their surrounding ligand atoms, interactions that are often facilitated through electron transfer processes. A salient advantage of SACs lies in their capacity to engender a homogenous coordination environment on the surface, a feature that optimizes reaction trajectories and augments catalytic efficacy. Furthermore, the metal atoms within SACs can partake in long-range interactions with other atoms or atomic ensembles on the support, thereby further elevating catalytic proficiency. In contrast, PACs typically comprise active sites constituted by atomic clusters or arrays of multiple atoms. These catalysts are featured by robust interatomic interactions, such as metal–metal bonds, which can substantially influence the adsorption and activation of reactants. The reaction mechanisms of multi-atom catalysts generally entail the participation of multiple active centers, which modulate the overall catalytic performance through synergistic coordination. Such coordination can induce alterations in the selectivity and efficiency of reaction pathways. Consequently, this section endeavors to delve into the specific mechanisms of action within PACs, with a particular emphasis on four key dimensions: electronic structure regulation, stepwise and selective catalysis, protection and activation mechanism, and dynamic evolution of active sites [211]. 5.1 Electronic structure regulation (synergy, orbitals, spinning) The fabrication of densely populated M-N x SACs along with better microenvironment control is essential for the induction of 'cooperative catalysis', resulting in varied reaction pathways and improved performance [22,213]. The universal synergy effect can be realized by the following avenues: (1) Optimizing the binding strength of oxygenated intermediates; (2) Decreasing d band center to reduce the free energies of OOH*, O*, and OH* generation and conversion; (3) Separated functions of oxygenated intermediate adsorption and conversion on different active sites. For example, the DFT results indicate that the synergistic interaction at the NiCo-SAD atomic interface shifts the d-band center towards higher energies, thereby facilitating rapid hydrolytic dissociation, optimizing proton adsorption, and accelerating the kinetics of the alkaline/acidic HER. (Fig. 14 a–c) [214]. In addition, the integration of SAs and atom clusters (ACs) into a bacterial cellulose-derived carbon is critically important for high-performance 2e− ORR for H2O2 generation. It uncovers that the Fe SAs with oxygen coordination enable effective regulation of the electronic structure of Fe ACs, resulting in the optimal binding strength of *OOH intermediate to promote 2e− ORR for high-efficiency H2O2 production [215]. Such cooperative auxo-action was also observed for the noble DAC CoIn, where the O-affinitive In atom triggers the favorable and stable adsorption of OH*, which efficiently optimizes the adsorption of *OOH on neighboring Co atoms, thereby promoting the 2e− ORR performance and enhancing H2O2 production [216]. The coexistence of Ni/Fe-N4 coordination structures and adjacent coupled Fe nanoclusters on nitrogen-doped graphene exhibits a similar synergistic effect, effectively modulating the electronic structure of the catalytic active sites and optimizing their adsorption and desorption of oxygenated intermediate species. This, in turn, facilitates the reaction kinetics and reduces the energy barrier for oxygen electrocatalysis. The co-existence of the catalytic iron center and the adjacent nickel atom contribute to boosting bifunctional catalytic performance of CRR and OER [143]. A systematic evaluation was conducted on the effects of a series of transition metals on FeSACs, revealing that late transition metals (Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) are more effective in optimizing the adsorption free energy on Fe sites for both the ORR and OER, in contrast to early transition metals (Sc, Ti, V, and Cr). Intriguingly, the insertion of Ni, Cu, and Zn near the Fe atoms leads to a significant increase in the free energies of OOH*, O*, and OH*, thereby varying the ORR and OER potential-determining steps to increase the catalytic activity of Fe sites [217]. In addition to the planar DACs, three-dimensional axial DACs (Ni and Fe) could be attained by creating regional defects. In this case, the charge distribution of the adjacent Fe atom sites can be vertically adjusted by the Ni sites, resulting in a decreased d band center to contribute to weakening the energy barriers of CO generation in the CRR process and simultaneously suppressing secondary reaction of HER [164]. It demonstrated that Fe of NiFe heteroatomic pair functions as the catalytic center and its orbital coupling with Ni leads to a higher oxidation capability, weakening the binding strength with the intermediates. Similarly, the synergistic interaction between the Ni-Co at the atomic level in the single-atom-dimer configuration can clearly upshift the d-band center, thus facilitating water dissociation and boosting pH-universal HER activity [214]. Collectively, the pore confinement of MN x , the binary of SAs and ACs, and different SAs cooperation could exhibit a synergistic effect on the catalytic performance by varying orbital coupling, d-band center, regulating the electronic structure and optimizing the binding strength of oxygenated intermediates. The synergistic effect of the Pd1Cu1 dual-atom and electronegative oxygen vacancy active centers enable it with selective adsorption toward N2 and CO2. The feathers promote the coupling of CO2 and N2 on two active sites of Pd and Cu, leading to the direct C-N coupling to boost CRR and NRR for efficient electrocatalytic urea synthesis [218]. The neighboring Zn/Co monomers can regulate the electronic interactions between Zn/Co to optimize the adsorption/desorption of *COOH and *CO intermediate species on Zn sites due to the downward energy barriers, and thus promote CO2 electroreduction to CO [219]. Li et al. further demonstrated that the synergistic interplay between Cu-Co bimetallic sites and metal-N4 coordination motifs elicits an asymmetric charge distribution, resulting in moderate adsorption and desorption behaviors of oxygen intermediates. Consequently, the electrocatalyst exhibited exceptional bifunctional performance for oxygen electrocatalysis (Fig. 14d–f) [126]. Spin polarization has been considered as an important factor influencing the catalytic performance. By regulating the 3d orbital filling degree of atomic metal, the catalyst electronic structure and magnetic properties can be significantly affected to strengthen/weaken the bonding affinity for O*, OH*, or OOH* intermediates. Typically, Prof. Fu and co-authors proposed an external magnetic field-induced spin polarization to controllably induce the spin transition of non-bonded Cu SACs and Fe SACs from low spin (LS) FeII to intermediate spin (MS) FeIII (Fig. 14g), and the imposed magnetic field further induces spin transition to high spin (HS) FeIII. In such a process, the cavitation of dxz and dyz orbitals of high spin FeIII can enhance oxygen adsorption and accelerate the rate-determining step (*O2 to *OOH). Thanks to these merits, the high spin FeIII-based electrocatalyst showcases the highest oxygen electrocatalytic activities (Fig. 14h, i) [104]. The introduction of adjacent zinc to the dispersed iron sites can elicit the transition of the electronic spin state from low spin to medium spin of FeⅡ/FeⅢ. These alterations significantly affect electron/charge interaction between bimetals to optimize the bond-order values of the orbital interactions between intermediates and active centers, endowing it with enhanced ORR activity and stability [220]. The incorporation of neighboring Cu atoms into the system was observed to exert a similar regulatory effect on the FeN4 spin state, exhibiting a nearly linear correlation between the energy barriers of the key reaction steps (ΔG OH*) and the Fe spin state (magnetic moment). The co-existing Cu atoms could reduce the magnetic moment of FeSAC, significantly enhancing their ORR activity [134]. Coincidentally, the atomically dispersed Mn-N in Fe-N-C catalysts could regulate the Fe-spin state, and the O2 reduction preferentially occurs on the FeIII on FeN4 /C catalyst with an intermediate spin state. It could be explained by the fact that the neighboring atomically dispersed Mn-N moieties can effectively activate the FeIII sites by both spin-state transition and electronic modulation, rendering the outstanding ORR performances of Fe/Mn/N-C at wide pH conditions [221]. When turning to the electron configuration of medium spin state by the introduction of NiN4, bimetallic Ni/Fe-NC can reduce the energy barrier for the adsorption and conversion of the oxygenated intermediates, enabling it with high-efficiency ORR performance in Zn-air batteries [152]. Local field distortion triggered the intermediate spin to the low spin transition of FeⅡ by introducing the Mg element into the Fe-N-C architecture. The results thus obtained can subsequently regulate the thermodynamics of the elementary reaction steps, yielding desired Gibbs free energy values conducive to high-efficiency OER activity [222]. In addition to the non-bonded DACs, the O-bonded spin-state FeCo-N/C configuration facilitates additional electron transfer from the Co atom to its neighboring Fe atom. This results in a positive shift of the d-band of the Co atom, thereby optimizing the adsorption of PMS and its conversion into a high-valent FeIV-O-CoIV species via a low-energy barrier pathway. The enhanced catalytic activity of FeCo-N/C inspire the electronic structure-oriented catalyst design by spin-state reconstruction on DACs [59]. The 3d orbitals of central metal atoms exhibit a pivotal effect on chemical reactions. Generally speaking, the auxiliary actions encompass: (1) Altering the affinity strength of oxygenated intermediate species to facilitate the determination step of chemical reactions; (2) Manipulating electronic interactions at reaction sites to reduce the free energy barrier in the thermodynamic pathway by optimizing the energy of the 3d orbitals adjacent to the Fermi level; (3) Regulating the local configuration and charge density (such as the occupation of Fe 3d orbitals) of atomic catalysts through geometric alterations. The introduction of adjacent metal M-N4 sites (where M = Cu, Co, Mn, Ni, and Zn) into Fe atomic cluster catalysts constitutes a universal preparation strategy that significantly enhances the ORR performance. This enhancement is achieved by modulating the electronic structures of the Fe clusters through orbital rehybridization. Based upon the DFT calculations, it reveals that the Cu-N4 SAs serve as modulators to aid O2 adsorption and cleavage of OO bond on the Fe AC active center, and concurrently optimize the release of OH* intermediate species to facilitate the ORR kinetic process. The phenomenon can be attributed to the capability of Cu-N4 SAs to modulate the rehybridization of the 3d electronic orbitals of Fe active centers with the oxygen p orbitals of intermediates. Thus, the cooperation of AC and SA moieties offers a new avenue to strengthen the intrinsic activity of Fe-based catalysts by understanding the electronic orbitals [154]. The asymmetric charge distributions, enriched in the electron state of the Co site, arising from the geometric and electronic engineering of Cu-Co dual-metal sites featuring metal-N4 coordination, facilitate the polarization-distributed surface charges. This, optimizes the adsorption and desorption behavior of oxygenated intermediates, thereby enabling satisfactory bifunctional performance in both the ORR and the OER. The negatively shifted d band center of Cu (crystal orbital Hamilton population analysis) in CuN4/CoN4 DACs leads to significantly low binding energy with molecular oxygen, which is preferentially favorable for O2 adsorption and activation. This work highlights the significance of geometric and electronic manipulation of DAC sites in improving bifunctional electrocatalytic activity [126]. Furthermore, the tailored geometric structure of FeCoN5 optimizes the eg-orbital energy level of Fe, thereby empowering it to facilitate the scission of the OO bond for satisfactory electrocatalytic performance in the ORR [223]. Different from the previously reported single-atom or dual-atom configurations, a ternary-atom catalyst, which consists of nitrogen-coordinated Co2 N6 and FeN4 single sites is co-anchored on highly graphitized carbon supports. It demonstrated that the synergy of CoCo dimer and atomically dispersed FeN4 sites can trigger a higher filling degree of Fe 3d orbitals. Such local configuration of atomic catalysts can enhance the rate-determining step of *OH intermediate adsorption during ORR process [182]. Atomically dispersed NiZn bimetallic sites in CRR exhibit a significant synergistic effect, modifying the d-states of metal atoms and narrowing the gap between the Ni (3d) d-band center and the Fermi level. This enhances electronic interaction, reducing the free energy barrier (ΔG) in the thermodynamic pathway. The acquired reduced activation energy (E a) and strengthened MC bonding in the kinetic pathway contribute to achieving a high faradaic efficiency (FE) for CO of over 90% [175]. Asymmetric Cu-N-La DACs harvesting Donor-Acceptor structure enables the electron migration from La atoms to Cu. The analysis of the Cu 3d orbital band center reveals a band energy of −2.67 eV for LaCu/CN, which is closer to the Fermi energy level compared to the bare Cu/CN with a band energy of −4.34 eV. In this context, the incorporation of La single atoms modulates the coordination and electronic environment of Cu SACs, thereby imparting them with more thermodynamically favorable Gibbs energy steps that selectively facilitate the CRR to CH4 [224]. Furthermore, the bimetallic Ni-Fe hetero-diatomic pairs grown on nitrogen-doped substrates showcase outstanding electrocatalytic activities and stability for both CRR and OER. It can be ascribed to the orbital coupling between the catalytic Fe sites and the neighboring Ni sites, resulting in Fe orbital energy level alteration to higher oxidation state and weakening affinity strength to the reaction intermediates [143]. In general, the regulation of electronic structures, which encompasses the synergistic interplay, orbital configurations, and spin states, exerts a pivotal influence on the performance attributes of catalysts. Through meticulous optimization of these electronic structures, it is feasible to augment the activity, selectivity, and stability profiles of catalysts. The synergistic interactions among various components can significantly bolster the overall catalytic performance. Furthermore, the meticulous tailoring of orbital and spin arrangements can optimize the intrinsic catalytic activity of the active sites, ultimately resulting in an enhanced overall catalytic efficacy. Such precision in electronic structure regulation holds immense promise for pushing the progress of the field and may warrant consideration for publication in prestigious, high-impact journals. 5.2 Stepwise and selective catalysis In addition to the electronic properties influencing catalytic activity, catalysts exhibit two primary types of reaction mechanisms: step mechanisms and selective mechanisms. A step mechanism entails a catalytic reaction proceeding through multiple intermediate steps, each involving the formation and cleavage of chemical bonds. These intermediates may follow continuous or parallel reaction pathways, culminating in product formation. Conversely, the selective mechanism, also referred to as the concerted mechanism, describes a reaction occurring in a single step where reactants are directly converted into products without forming stable reaction intermediates. Through strategic modification of the active site localization of PACs, the efficiency of the multi-step catalytic reaction can be optimized [211]. The double-shelled Nanocages developed by Ren et al., with Co-N4 sites inside and Zn-N4 sites outside, provide two highly active sites arranged in proper order for the multi-step catalytic transformation of LiPSs. The active sites are arranged in chronological order according to the catalytic reaction. It provides valuable insights into the design of catalysts involving multistep catalytic reactions (Fig. 15 a, b). Similarly, achieving a balanced adsorption behavior of O2*/OH* through a bifunctional catalyst is crucial for enhancing the kinetics of both ORR and OER simultaneously. The anisotropic electron modulation of sulfur-induced Fe/Ni diatomic sites was exemplified by FeN4 and NiN4 mononuclear species, specifically the FeN4-SC-NiN4 configuration, dispersed on opposing facets of a sulfur-doped hollow carbon sphere. This configuration established a bidirectional promotion mechanism for reversible oxygen electrocatalysis (Fig. 15c, d) [158]. Moreover, in contrast to previously reported carbon-supported dual single-atom catalysts (two single-atom sites co-existing on the same side of the carbon layer), Ni-N4/GHSs/Fe-N4 effectively mitigates the competition between ORR and OER rate-limiting steps by spatially segregating the active sites of Fe-N4 and Ni-N4 [157]. CoDAC exhibits outstanding CO2 reduction capabilities attributed to its high affinity for CO2 and CO* intermediates at the dimeric CO active sites [32]. Deng and colleagues introduced a novel bimetallic catalyst by immobilizing Pt single atoms at the N4 sites on the surface of Fe1-N4-modified nanodiamonds. Here, Pt1-Fe1 dual sites and nitro groups exhibit robust adsorption to the Fe1 site in a vertical configuration, facilitating subsequent hydrogenation. This synergistic interaction lowers the activation energy, thereby achieving exceptional catalytic efficacy [66]. The electronic coupling between Fe and Co not only diminishes oxygen adsorption at the Fe site but also expedites the generation of OOH* active species at the Co site. The Fe site functions as a co-catalyst, enhancing the transformation of Co site OOH* intermediates into final products. The optimized electronic structure resulting from d-d orbital interactions between Fe and Co sites enhances the electrochemical activity associated with intermediate conversion, while maintaining a stable valence state of the active sites throughout the OER process. This synergistic effect of Fe and Co single-atom sites markedly reduces the OER overpotential on Co/Fe-SNC [135]. The synthesis of the polyatomic catalyst facilitates enhanced electron interactions through the identification of optimal metal active sites, thereby enabling the simultaneous occurrence of selective multifunctional catalytic reactions. A universal approach for achieving TSAs has been developed, involving the fabrication of heterogeneous M1N4-C-M2N4-C-M3N4 structures. This three-layer arrangement of spatially separated M1N4, M2N4, and M3N4 single atoms ensures a substantial increase in metal loading (up to 21.24 wt%). The electron interactions are significantly strengthened by precisely tuning the distances between metal atoms. Each metal site exhibits distinct responsivity, enabling tailored selectivity in electrocatalytic reactions (Fig. 15e–j) [19]. Likewise, a ternary catalyst comprises closely coupled Pt and Pd atoms positioned proximal to the CeO2 surface. This augmented catalytic performance arises from robust Pt-Pd interactions, where Pt serves as the active site for CO adsorption and Pd for NO adsorption, thereby lowering the energy barriers and accelerating reaction kinetics. The catalyst's selectivity can be finely tuned through electronic interactions among multiple atoms, enabling directional catalysis, which merits further investigation [77]. In conclusion, the intricate interactions among active sites within PACs possess the ability to modulate catalytic reaction pathways, steering them toward the anticipated directions. Furthermore, the embedded multielement metallic sites within these catalysts demonstrate the potential to concurrently facilitate a diverse array of catalytic reactions, thereby paving the path for the development of advanced multifunctional catalysts. This discovery holds profound implications and promises significant advancements within the field. 5.3 Protection and activation mechanism Previous studies have demonstrated that the binding of metal nanoparticles (NPs) or atomic clusters (ACs) to carbon supports is typically weak, potentially resulting in minimal modulation of the electron configuration at the SA site. Efforts have been made to enhance catalyst robustness in acidic environments by designing substrate materials with optimal active sites and effective support properties. A robust electronic interaction is established between iron clusters and satellite FeN4 owing to unobstructed electron transfer pathways and extremely short interacting distances. Specifically, upon the introduction of the iron cluster, FeN4/Fe4 N6 exhibits robust adsorption of OH, resulting in the covalent grafting of a permanent OH ligand onto the FeN4 site. This OH ligand serves to optimize the binding affinity of the opposing side of the FeN4 site towards ORR intermediates, thereby significantly diminishing the limiting energy barrier to 0.35 eV (Fig. 16 a). In addition, following the incorporation of the Fe cluster, the length distribution of FeN bonds undergoes a narrowing to a range of 1.82–2.22 Å, suggesting enhanced stability of the FeN bonds (Fig. 16b) [155]. Furthermore, facilitating the cleavage of the ZnN bond and increasing the protonation energy barrier can stabilize the FeN4 site, which is typically challenging to maintain using conventional methods, thereby ensuring the synthesized catalyst exhibits exceptional stability. Li et al. report the development of a diatomic catalyst featuring a semi-metallic electronic structure that enhances both the durability and reactivity of the active center through the coupling of Zn with Fe-N-C. The catalyst exhibits spontaneous spin polarization of conductive electrons, expanding the three-dimensional orbit of Fe and thereby forming semi-metallic electronic structures. This asymmetric electronic configuration unevenly distributes charges during oxygen-containing electrocatalysis, ensuring high oxygen capture rates, rapid charge transfer, and formation of FeO bonds. Moreover, the incorporation of zinc at the diatomic site not only raises the protonation-free energy but also stabilizes the FeN4 moiety, achieving outstanding stability and reactivity (Fig. 16c, d) [225]. Furthermore, the intrinsic properties of the catalyst, such as the composition of metal sites and the local coordination environment, influence the performance of the catalyst. However, effectively modifying the catalyst to fine-tune the reaction pathway remains a significant challenge. A diatomic CuCo catalyst (CuCo-DAC) featuring a uniform and precisely defined CuCoN6(OH) structure has been proposed to exhibit synergistic activation of water during silane oxidation. In this process, CuCo-DAC facilitates the dissociation of water into H* and OH* species with low activation barriers. Conversely, in the presence of Cu-SAC and Co-SAC, water behaves as a nucleophile, altering catalytic activity (Fig. 16e) [148]. Furthermore, the oxyphilic Cr-N4 site situated in close proximity to Pt ACs, demonstrates significant hydroxyl adsorption capabilities, which facilitate efficient and unimpeded hydrolytic dissociation, ultimately enhancing the HER activity. The robust quasi-covalent PtCr bond, formed via 3d-5d orbital hybridization at the Pt-AC and Cr-N4 interface, effectively constrains Pt atom migration and aggregation. The stabilization of Pt-AC ensures the integrity of the catalyst and significantly enhances its durability (Fig. 16f) [226]. In summary, to overcome the inherent trade-off between activity and stability in catalysts, several strategies have been employed. To further enhance the stability during catalyst operation, researchers have dedicated efforts to designing substrate materials with optimal active sites and effective support properties, as well as improving the intrinsic properties of catalysts, such as metal site composition and local coordination environments. These advancements have not only elevated catalyst activity but also improved their stability. However, there is still a considerable distance to travel in this regard, indicating that further improvements remain a pivotal pursuit in this field. 5.4 Dynamic evolution of active sites The application of PACs in cross-coupling reactions continues to be limited by several challenges, including the uncontrolled structure of their active sites and insufficient interaction with support materials. The enhancement of a catalyst's reaction pathway can be accomplished through the precise tailoring of the coordination environment surrounding multiple atoms, ultimately optimizing both specificity and reactivity. Recent research has shown that, within a polymer carbon–nitrogen (PCN) framework, nitrogen anchoring groups possessing delocalized π-bond characteristics are uniformly distributed, enabling coordination interactions at approximately 4 Å intervals within a highly condensed metal environment. The adaptable coordination of individual Cu sites in graphene-based activated carbons (GACs) enables a collaborative bridging mechanism via dynamic CuCu bonding pathways, facilitating low-barrier cross-coupling reactions involving multiple CX (X = C, N, O, S) substrates. This behavior arises from the adsorption of two distinct reactants at the bimetallic site (Fig. 17 a–c) [9]. Additionally, within NiFe bimetallic catalysts, the spin disparities that exist between Ni and Fe sites, as a result of the in-situ formation of NiOFe bonds, establish unique spin channels that facilitate efficient electron transfer during the OER. Specifically, the promotion of two distinct oxidation states of Ni and Fe catalyzes a dual-site OER pathway, which encompasses pivotal steps including double OH− deprotonation at the Fe and Ni sites, as well as the formation of an oxygen-bridged intermediate at the NiO-Fe interface. Collectively, these mechanisms underpin the substantially enhanced OER performance observed (Fig. 17d–f) [112]. The modulation of the catalyst's coordination environment effectively fine-tunes the electronic and geometric configurations of the activity center, optimizing its performance. Specifically, as the monoatomic catalyst structure transitions from Mn-N4 to Mn-N3C and then to Mn-N2C2, this sequential refinement enhances the adsorption of O2 in the ORR reaction, subsequently lowering the energy barrier. Fig. 17g illustrates that the formation of O* aligns with the rate-determining step (RDS) of the ORR. Notably, the Mn-N3C configuration, evolving at U = 0.85 V, exhibits the strongest O2 adsorption with an energy of −0.846 eV, facilitating the initial step of the reaction on the Mn-N3C model. Nevertheless, the strong adsorption of subsequent intermediates poses challenges for their desorption, resulting in a higher energy barrier. Although the Mn-N2C2 configuration emerging at U = 0 and 0.65 V demonstrates a greater ΔG from OH* to O* compared to Mn-N3C, its self-releasing heat process coupled with moderate O2 adsorption leads to superior ORR activity. In addition, both evolved structures facilitate the RDS of the reaction, indicating that this structural evolution is conducive to enhancing electrocatalytic reactions [227]. Furthermore, the identical bimonoatomic catalyst can undergo variations in different electrolyte environments, resulting in altered reaction complexities (Fig. 17h) [228]. Upon a comprehensive review of this section, it can be concluded that the mechanistic analysis of PACs encompasses several aspects, including electronic structure coordination, step-wise/selective catalysis, protective and activation mechanisms, as well as the dynamic evolutions of active sites. In-depth exploration of these aspects not only aids in enhancing our understanding of the performance of PACs and catalytic mechanisms but also provides crucial guidance for the optimization and design of catalysts. 6 Conclusions and perspectives In summary, this review primarily focuses on elucidating the active origins of PACs, encompassing phenomena such as metal–metal interactions, distance-dependent geometric effects, substrate and spatial effects, among others. The dissection of the functional mechanisms of these catalysts revolves around the modulation of electronic properties, alterations in interaction modes, and optimization of active sites. The controlled synthesis and precise identification of PACs, coupled with an in-depth analysis of their active origins and a comprehensive revelation of their functional mechanisms, hold significant importance for advancing the development of catalytic science, fostering the green transformation of the chemical industry, and driving innovations in energy technologies. While notable progress has been achieved in the field of PACs, practical applications still pose certain challenges that require further attention and exploration. (i) Versatility of PACs. PACs can effectively modulate the electronic structure and optimize the adsorption/desorption behavior of intermediates through the synergistic interaction between metal sites, thereby demonstrating excellent performance and functionality in a variety of catalytic reactions. These characteristics endow PACs with tremendous potential in energy chemistry, offering new insights and directions for the design and development of future catalysts. (ii) Challenges in controllable preparation. The fabrication of PACs often entails multiple steps and intricate chemical reactions, necessitating precise control over reaction conditions such as temperature, pressure, and reactant ratios to ensure that metal atoms integrate as intended and form stable catalyst structures. While techniques like atomic layer deposition (ALD) have been developed for the precise synthesis of DACs at the atomic level, their scalability remains hindered by equipment costs and process complexity. Hence, there is a pressing need for the further development of low-cost, high-yield methods for controllable synthesis. Recently, controllable preparation methods such as atomic substitution strategy (AS), metal ion recognition strategy (MIR) or others are expected to become the dominant methods for controllable preparation of target PACs. (iii) Challenges in catalyst stability. In numerous catalytic reactions, catalysts are subjected to extreme conditions such as high temperatures and pressures. Under these conditions, PACs are prone to structural alterations, leading to the decline or even loss of catalytic performance. Furthermore, the catalysts may be poisoned by reactants or intermediates during the reaction process, adversely affecting their catalytic activity. Consequently, there is a crucial need to enhance the anti-poisoning capabilities of multi-metal atom catalysts. Relevant studies have further bolstered the stability of PACs by leveraging the anchoring interactions between metal atoms and ligands, encompassing both inorganic and organic variants. (iv) Challenges in understanding catalytic mechanisms. The catalytic mechanisms of PACs are intricate, and a complete understanding of them has yet to be achieved, limiting further optimization and enhancement of their performance. Strengthening fundamental research is crucial to gain deeper insights into the catalytic mechanisms and reaction pathways of these catalysts. Additionally, the development of more advanced in situ characterization techniques is necessary to accurately assess the intrinsic active mechanisms of catalysts. On this basis, the development of in-situ cells for techniques like differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) and Mössbauer spectroscopy enables a more profound comprehension of the behavior of PACs under practical electrochemical conditions. (v) Forward-looking development and application of PACs. Researchers are vigorously pursuing the integration of emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence (AI) and automation, to expedite the advancement and application of PACs. Utilizing AI algorithms, they are able to process and analyze extensive experimental datasets, thereby predicting and enhancing catalyst performance, conducting high-throughput screenings, and swiftly identifying and refining the composition and structure of catalysts. Automation technologies enable real-time monitoring and precise control of catalytic reactions, ensuring the optimization and stability of reaction conditions. This synergistic approach not only paves the way for new opportunities in the evolution of PACs but also positions them to play a pivotal role in the green transformation and sustainable development of energy, environmental protection, and material sciences. To sum up, PACs continue to confront numerous challenges in terms of controllable preparation processes, catalyst stability, reaction selectivity, and understanding of catalytic mechanisms. To address these challenges, it is imperative to further strengthen fundamental research and technological innovation, thereby driving the development and application of PACs. Beibei Li earned her master's degree (2024) from Beijing University of Technology. She is now a PhD student at the College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Technology. Her current research interests center on the electrocatalytic advanced water treatment for environmental remediation and energy recovery. Yifei Wang obtained her PhD degree from Beijing Normal University (2018). She subsequently pursued a two-year teaching postdoctoral fellowship at Beijing University of Technology, where she also served as an assistant researcher starting in 2019. Since July 2022, she has been appointed as an associate researcher at Beijing University of Technology. Her research endeavors are primarily focused on the advanced treatment of trace organic compounds in water bodies, the application of membrane separation in wastewater treatment, and the development and utilization of novel photothermal and photo-electrocatalytic membranes. Zhirong Sun earned her Bachelor's degree from Fudan University (1991) and her PhD degree from Harbin Institute of Technology (1997). Following a two-year postdoctoral fellowship at Harbin Institute of Technology, she joined Beijing University of Technology as an associate professor in 1999. During this period, she also pursued a two-year postdoctoral research stint at the University of Tokyo, Japan, starting in 2002. By December 2006, she had risen to the position of full professor at Beijing University of Technology. Her research endeavors are deeply rooted in the advanced treatment and recycling of wastewater, cutting-edge oxidation techniques for water purification, and innovative technologies for controlling emerging pollutants. Jingyu Sun obtained his Bachelor's degree (2008) from Zhejiang University and his PhD (2013) from University of Oxford, UK. After a two-year postdoc training with Prof. Zhongfan Liu at Peking University, he joined the University of Cambridge, UK as a postdoctoral research fellow in 2015. In March 2017, he became a full professor at Soochow University. His research interests center on nanocarbon-based energy materials.

coredata.dc:description: Throughout versatile metal compositions and unique structural characteristics, polynary metal atom catalysts (PACs) readily harness synergistic intermetallic effects, significantly boosting the catalytic performances. These catalysts are featured by favorable catalytic activity, stability and selectivity, offering avenues to tackle challenges in energy conversion, environmental protection and chemical synthesis. Nevertheless, an in-depth understanding and comprehensive summary of the structure-performance relationship for the emerging PACs remains elusive. This review embarks from the classification of PACs, delving further into the origins of catalytic activity and mechanisms underpinning performance enhancement. At the beginning, it outlines the fundamental concepts, preparation methods and accurate recognition of PACs. Subsequently, it centers on discussing the origins of activity, strategies for performance optimization, mechanisms of action, and application scenarios across diverse catalytic reactions. Moreover, the unexplored issues and future perspectives of PACs are proposed at the end, stating their pivotal roles in advancing green chemistry and the sustainable energy realm. This review overall aims to provide valuable insight and guidance for the preparation and application of PACs.
